prompt:
You are a helpful assistant that can generate a clinical note from a conversation transcript between a patient and a doctor. 

The conversation transcript is given below: 

Doctor: Good morning, how are you feeling today?
Patient: I'm okay, thanks. I've been feeling a bit tired lately.
Doctor: Hmm, I see. Have you been feeling tired for a long time?
Patient: Yes, I started feeling more and more tired since 2014.
Doctor: I see. Have you noticed any other symptoms besides fatigue?
Patient: Yes, I've been having pain in my left lower side for a while now.
Doctor: Okay, I understand. When did the pain become severe?
Patient: It became really bad a few months ago, so I went to the emergency room.
Doctor: I see. And what happened at the emergency room?
Patient: They did a CT scan and found an infiltrate into my greater omentum and multiple nodules in my small bowel mesentery.
Doctor: I see. Was there any fluid buildup in your abdomen?
Patient: No, there wasn't any.
Doctor: Okay. And were there any masses found in your ovaries?
Patient: Yes, there were masses on both my right and left ovaries.
Doctor: I see. And what was done about that?
Patient: I was taken to the operating room in March and they took multiple biopsies. They also removed my left ovary and appendix.
Doctor: I see. And what did the pathology report show?
Patient: It showed a mature cystic teratoma and extensive malignant peritoneal mesothelioma.
Doctor: I understand. And what happened next?
Patient: Another CT scan was done in May and it showed that the malignant peritoneal mesothelioma was infiltrating my omentum and had accumulated as a mass in my pelvis.
Doctor: I see. And what was the definitive treatment for her malignant peritoneal mesothelioma?
Patient: I had a greater and lesser omentectomy, cholecystectomy, pelvic peritonectomy with hysterectomy and right oophorectomy along with cytoreductive surgery of the small and large bowel surfaces. And then I had HIPEC with cisplatin, doxorubicin, and systemic ifosfamide with Mesna.
Doctor: I see. And what happened during the HIPEC procedure?
Patient: They used scissor dissection to remove a layer of tumor from my large and small bowel surfaces along with my large and small bowel mesenteric surfaces. And to rule out disease within the mesenteric lymph nodes, they harvested six of these lymph nodes during the HIPEC chemotherapy.
Doctor: I see. And what happened to the harvested lymph nodes?
Patient: Portions of the nodes were sent for histopathologic analysis and other portions were sent for pharmacologic analysis of the intraperitoneal drug, doxorubicin.
Doctor: I see. And what were the results of the doxorubicin within blood, peritoneal fluid, lymph nodes, and tumor?
Patient: The area under the curve ratio of lymph node doxorubicin to plasma doxorubicin was 30. The area under the curve ratio of tumor nodules to plasma was [].
Doctor: I see. Thank you for explaining all that to me. Do you have any questions or concerns?
Patient: No, I don't think so.
Doctor: Okay, well if you think of anything, don't hesitate to ask. I'll see you again soon for a follow-up appointment.
Patient: Okay, thank you.
ideal_response:
This 35 year old woman began noticing increasing fatigue in 2014. The fatigue and left lower quadrant pain became increasingly severe so that she went an emergency room. On 19 February 2018, a CT scan was performed that showed an infiltrate into the greater omentum and multiple nodules associated with small bowel mesentery. There was no ascites. Masses were present on both the right and left ovaries. On 14 March 2018, she was taken to the operating room where multiple biopsies were taken. Her left ovary and appendix were removed. Pathology showed a mature cystic teratoma and extensive malignant peritoneal mesothelioma. Multiple biopsies from omentum, surface of uterus, peritoneum from the abdominal wall, and peritoneum from the small bowel showed malignant peritoneal mesothelioma.
Repeat CT on 2 May 2018 showed malignant peritoneal mesothelioma infiltrating the omentum and accumulating as a diffuse mass in the pelvis. The small bowel mesentery showed multiple prominent lymph nodes. For definitive treatment of her malignant peritoneal mesothelioma, the patient was taken back to the operating room on 3 May 2018. At that time she had a greater and lesser omentectomy, cholecystectomy, pelvic peritonectomy with hysterectomy and right oophorectomy along with cytoreductive surgery of the small and large bowel surfaces. HIPEC was performed with cisplatin, doxorubicin, and systemic ifosfamide with Mesna (2-Mercaptoethanesulfonic acid sodium). During the HIPEC procedure Mayo scissor dissection removed a layer tumor from large and small bowel surfaces along with large and small bowel mesenteric surfaces []. In order to rule out disease within the mesenteric lymph nodes, six of these lymph nodes were harvested during the HIPEC chemotherapy []. Portions of the node were sent for histopathologic analysis and other portions were sent for pharmacologic analysis of the intraperitoneal drug, doxorubicin. The results of the doxorubicin within blood, peritoneal fluid, lymph nodes, and tumor are shown in . The area under the curve ratio of lymph node doxorubicin to plasma doxorubicin was 30. The area under the curve ratio of tumor nodules to plasma was

prompt:
You are a helpful assistant that can generate a clinical note from a conversation transcript between a patient and a doctor. 

The conversation transcript is given below: 

Doctor: "Hello there, how are you feeling today?"
Patient: "I'm feeling okay, thank you."
Doctor: "So, you presented to the antenatal clinic at 19 weeks and 3 days' gestation to discuss the results of your morphology scan. Is that correct?"
Patient: "Yes, that's right."
Doctor: "The scan demonstrated a grade 4 placenta previa covering the cervical os. Can you tell me more about your medical history? I see you had a craniotomy in 2006 for Arnold Chiari malformation and correction of a Syringomyelia in 2005."
Patient: "Yes, that's correct. I also suffer from irritable bowel syndrome but I'm not taking any regular medications."
Doctor: "I see. And your first pregnancy resulted in a spontaneous miscarriage that did not require dilatation and curettage. Your second pregnancy resulted in a planned elective caesarean due to concerns about raised intracranial pressure during labor."
Patient: "That's right."
Doctor: "During your current pregnancy, the morphology scan demonstrated a small omphalocele but otherwise no significant structural defects and estimated fetal weight was noted to be within the normal range. However, during the clinic review, the fetus was found to have a heart rate well below 100 bpm. Repeat ultrasound the following day confirmed IUFD."
Patient: "Yes, unfortunately that's what happened."
Doctor: "This ultrasound also demonstrated evidence of an abnormally invasive placenta with the appearance of dysplastic vascular hypertrophy. An obstetric MRI was performed which supported the diagnosis of morbidly adherent placenta. This showed a low lying inhomogeneous placenta, dysplastic vascular hypertrophy, ill-defined placental bands, and an overall impression of some areas of increta with no overt evidence of percreta."
Patient: "I see."
Doctor: "We discussed options with you and you decided for conservative management in order to optimize your chance of preserving your fertility. This was balanced against potential complications of prolonged conservative management of an IUFD, including sepsis and coagulopathy. We made a plan for serial ultrasounds as an outpatient, to be followed by induction of labor when placental blood flow was no longer detectable. However, you were admitted to the hospital with abdominal cramping and associated small antepartum hemorrhage 27 days following IUFD confirmation."
Patient: "Yes, that's right."
Doctor: "An ultrasound scan at 31 days showed a minimal reduction in blood flow. We need to closely monitor your condition and consider the best course of action going forward. Do you have any questions for me?"
Patient: "No, not at the moment."
Doctor: "Okay, we'll continue to monitor your condition and keep you informed of any changes. Thank you for coming in today."
(Patient eventually passes away)
Doctor: "I'm sorry to inform you that the patient has passed away. We will be in contact with the family to discuss next steps."
ideal_response:
A 31-year-old gravida 3 para 1 patient presented to antenatal clinic at 19 weeks and 3 days' gestation to discuss the results of her morphology scan which had demonstrated a grade 4 placenta previa covering the cervical os. She had a medical history significant for Arnold Chiari malformation requiring craniotomy in 2006 as well as correction of a Syringomyelia in 2005. She also suffers from irritable bowel syndrome but was taking no regular medications and had a BMI of 23. Her first pregnancy resulted in a spontaneous miscarriage that did not require dilatation and curettage. Her second pregnancy resulted in a planned elective caesarean due to concerns about raised intracranial pressure during labour, as recommended by her neurologist. She had routine antenatal care this pregnancy which had been unremarkable to date.
The morphology scan demonstrated a small omphalocele but otherwise no significant structural defects and estimated foetal weight was noted to be within the normal range. During the clinic review, the fetus was found to have a heart rate well below 100 bpm. Repeat ultrasound the following day confirmed IUFD. This ultrasound also demonstrated evidence of an abnormally invasive placenta with the appearance of dysplastic vascular hypertrophy. An obstetric MRI was performed which supported the diagnosis of morbidly adherent placenta. This showed a low lying inhomogeneous placenta, dysplastic vascular hypertrophy, ill-defined placental bands, and an overall impression of some areas of increta with no overt evidence of percreta.
Options were discussed with the patient who decided for conservative management in order to optimise her chance of preserving her fertility. This was balanced against potential complications of prolonged conservative management of an IUFD, including sepsis and coagulopathy. A plan was made for serial ultrasounds as an outpatient, to be followed by induction of labour when placental blood flow was no longer detectable. Twenty-seven days following IUFD confirmation, the patient was admitted to hospital with abdominal cramping and associated small antepartum haemorrhage (APH).
Ultrasound scan at 31 days showed a minimal reduction in blood flow

prompt:
You are a helpful assistant that can generate a clinical note from a conversation transcript between a patient and a doctor. 

The conversation transcript is given below: 

Doctor: Good morning, how are you feeling today?
Patient: I'm not feeling very good, doctor.
Doctor: I see. You were admitted to the inpatient ward with a complaint of suicidal ideation. Can you tell me more about that?
Patient: Yes, I have been struggling with suicidal thoughts for a while now.
Doctor: I see. You have a past history of multiple psychiatric disorders, including BPD, MDD, and anxiety issues. Can you tell me more about those?
Patient: Yes, I have been dealing with those for about eight to 10 years now.
Doctor: I see. It says in your clinical note that you have had multiple suicide attempts in the past. Can you tell me more about those?
Patient: Yes, the most recent one was two weeks ago when I tried to suffocate myself with the help of a medical device tubing.
Doctor: I see. On inquiry, you said you just wanted to feel the pain, not kill yourself. Can you tell me more about that?
Patient: Yes, I just wanted to feel something, anything. I feel so numb all the time.
Doctor: I see. On further questioning, you were found to have passive suicidal thoughts as well as an active plan to harm yourself. Can you tell me more about that?
Patient: Yes, I was planning on killing myself with the carbon monoxide poisoning by turning on the engines of four cars parked in the garage.
Doctor: I see. According to you, you felt better at the time of the last admission and these suicidal thoughts just returned two to three days back. Can you tell me more about that?
Patient: Yes, I thought I was doing better, but these thoughts just keep coming back.
Doctor: I see. It says in your clinical note that you had multiple admissions and emergency department visits related to your psychiatric conditions as well as five suicidal attempts. Can you tell me more about those?
Patient: Yes, I have been struggling with this for a long time.
Doctor: I see. During one of your admissions, you were evaluated for ECT by a psychiatrist but the decision was made in favor of dialectical behavior therapy (DBT) as they felt these symptoms are because of your BPD. Can you tell me more about that?
Patient: Yes, they thought that DBT would be more helpful for me in coping with my day-to-day issues.
Doctor: I see. According to you, you have been compliant with the therapy that has helped you in coping with your day-to-day issues. Can you tell me more about that?
Patient: Yes, it has helped me a lot, but I still struggle with these active and passive suicidal thoughts.
Doctor: I see. According to you, you have never recovered from these active and passive suicidal thoughts which have progressed to an even worse state in the last four months. Can you tell me more about that?
Patient: Yes, they just keep getting worse and worse. I don't know what to do anymore.
Doctor: I see. On further evaluation, you reported feelings of hopelessness and worthlessness most of the time along with a guilt of things for what you have done in the past. Can you tell me more about that?
Patient: Yes, I just feel so worthless all the time. I can't stop thinking about all the mistakes I have made.
Doctor: I see. You also reported a decrease in sleep to about five hours per night along with difficulty in staying asleep and poor appetite and energy. Can you tell me more about that?
Patient: Yes, I just can't seem to sleep or eat anymore. I feel so tired all the time.
Doctor: I see. It's important that we address these issues and get you the help you need. We will work together to come up with a plan that works for you.
ideal_response:
A 33-year-old woman was admitted to psychiatry inpatient with a complaint of suicidal ideation. The patient has a past history of multiple psychiatric disorders like BPD, MDD, and anxiety issues for about last eight to 10 years. She had multiple suicide attempts in the past most recent being two weeks back when she tried to suffocate herself with the help of a medical device tubing. On inquiry, she said she just wanted to feel the pain, not kill herself. On further questioning, she was found to have passive suicidal thoughts as well as an active plan to harm herself. Her plan was to kill herself with the carbon monoxide poisoning by turning on the engines of four cars parked in the garage. According to her, she felt better at the time of the last admission and these suicidal thoughts just returned two to three days back. She had multiple admissions and emergency department (ED) visits related to her psychiatric conditions as well as five suicidal attempts. During one of her admission when she took multiple tablets of Advil® (Pfizer, New York, USA) in an attempt to kill herself, she was evaluated for ECT by a psychiatrist but the decision was made in favor of dialectical behavior therapy (DBT) as they felt these symptoms are because of her BPD. According to the patient she has been compliant with the therapy that has helped her in coping day-to-day issues. The patient also confirmed that she has never recovered from these active and passive suicidal thoughts which have progressed to even worse state in the last four months.
On further evaluation, the patient reported feelings of hopelessness and worthlessness most of the time along with a guilt of things for what she has done in the past. She also reported a decrease in sleep to about five hours per night along with difficulty in staying asleep and poor appetite and energy. Her concentration was normal. She continues to engage in her interests in reading and photography

prompt:
You are a helpful assistant that can generate a clinical note from a conversation transcript between a patient and a doctor. 

The conversation transcript is given below: 

Doctor: Hello, how are you feeling today?
Patient: I'm okay, just a little nervous.
Doctor: I understand. Looking at your medical history, I see that you have a family history of ovarian cancer on your maternal side. Have you experienced any symptoms related to that?
Patient: No, I haven't had any symptoms related to ovarian cancer.
Doctor: Okay, let's move on to your personal history. I see that you were clinically and radiologically diagnosed with a mass on your right breast as a fibroadenoma 2 years ago. Can you tell me more about that?
Patient: Yes, I had a mass on my right breast that was diagnosed as a fibroadenoma 2 years ago.
Doctor: And did that mass grow in size?
Patient: Yes, the same mass had a growth of 2 cm, so an incisional biopsy was performed at another institution.
Doctor: I see. And what were the results of that biopsy?
Patient: It was positive for mucinous carcinoma, and I was referred to your institution for treatment and follow up.
Doctor: Okay, thank you for that information. After a revision of the biopsy slides, we found a tumor composed of mucinous lakes with numerous tumor cells of medium to large size with a moderate amount of eosinophilic cytoplasm, confirming the presence of pure mucinous carcinoma. We couldn't identify the tumor size and surgical margins by no prior radiological and pathological report. The tumor was classified as a low grade tumor (G1) based on the Scarff Bloom Richardson scale. We didn't observe perineural or vascular invasion. On immunohistochemistry the results were 100% and 90% positive for estrogen and progesterone receptors respectively with high intensity, and HER2 receptors negative.
Patient: Okay.
Doctor: Moving on to your physical examination, we saw a surgical injury. Upon palpation, this zone felt indurated, edematous, and presented as a rough irregular texture. No other lesions were found. An ultrasound was performed, showing avascular distortion and a heterogeneous mass with microcysts. MRI showed a hypointense irregular mass that indicates a mild enhancement in contrast sequences and a hyperintense sequence in SPAIR. The evaluation of the lymph nodes was not suspicious for metastasis.
Patient: Okay, what does that mean?
Doctor: Based on these findings, we performed a partial mastectomy and a sentinel lymph node biopsy. Pathological findings showed a residual mass of 25 mm of pure mucinous carcinoma with negative surgical margins. Sentinel lymph node was negative for metastasis.
Patient: That's good news, right?
Doctor: Yes, it is. However, molecular screening with EndoPredict clinic showed a score of 2.7, classifying it as a low risk. That's why we decided to treat you with tamoxifen because of your positivity to receptors and low risk showed in molecular assay.
Patient: Okay, thank you for explaining everything to me.
Doctor: Of course. It's important that you understand your condition and treatment. Do you have any other questions or concerns?
Patient: No, I think I understand everything.
Doctor: Alright then, please make sure to follow up with us regularly and take your medication as prescribed. If you have any further questions or concerns, don't hesitate to reach out. We're here to help you.
Patient (or Patient's Family): Thank you so much for your help and support.
ideal_response:
A 25-year-old Mexican female with family history of ovarian cancer at her maternal side and personal history of a mass on her right breast clinically and radiologically diagnosed as fibroadenoma 2 years ago. The same mass had a growth of 2 cm so an incisional biopsy was performed at another institution. This was positive for mucinous carcinoma, and the patient was referred to our institution for treatment and follow up.
At our institution in the biopsy slides revision, we found a tumor composed of mucinous lakes with numerous tumor cells of medium to large size with a moderate amount of eosinophilic cytoplasm confirming the presence of pure mucinous carcinoma. We could not identify the tumor size and surgical margins by no prior radiological and pathological report. []. The tumor was classified as a Low grade tumor (G1) based on the Scarff Bloom Richardson scale. We did not observe perineural or vascular invasion. On immunohistochemistry the results were 100% and 90% positive for estrogen and progesterone receptors respectively with high intensity, and HER2 receptors negative.
On physical examination a surgical injury was seen. Upon palpation, this zone felt indurated, edematous and presented as a rough irregular texture. No other lesions were found. An ultrasound was performed, showing avascular distortion and a heterogeneous mass with microcysts (white arrows) []. MRI showed a hypointense irregular mass that indicates a mild enhancement in contrast sequences and a hyperintense sequence in SPAIR. The evaluation of the lymph nodes was not suspicious for metastasis.
With the radiological suspicious of residual tumor and pathological findings accomplished at our institution a partial mastectomy and a sentinel lymph node biopsy was performed. Pathological findings showed a residual mass of 25 mm of pure mucinous carcinoma with negative surgical margins. Sentinel lymph node was negative for metastasis.
Molecular screening with EndoPredict clinic showed a score of 2.7 classifying it as a low risk, reason why this patient was treated with tamoxifen because her positivity to receptors and low risk showed in molecular assay

prompt:
You are a helpful assistant that can generate a clinical note from a conversation transcript between a patient and a doctor. 

The conversation transcript is given below: 

Doctor: Hello, how are you feeling today?
Patient: Hello, I'm feeling okay.
Doctor: Can you tell me what brought you here today?
Patient: I have been experiencing dyspnea for a while now.
Doctor: I see. Can you tell me a little bit about your medical history?
Patient: Well, I used to be a nurse until I was 72 years old. I don't have any particular past or familial history.
Doctor: Alright. Did you have any occupational exposure to asbestos?
Patient: No, I didn't.
Doctor: Alright. Did you live in an environment contaminated with asbestos?
Patient: No, I didn't.
Doctor: Okay. Let's talk about the history of your present illness. You presented with abnormal chest radiographs, is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's correct. I was at a community health screening in July 2006 and they found something wrong. But I didn't pay much attention to it because I wasn't experiencing any symptoms.
Doctor: I see. And then, when was the next time you had a chest radiograph taken?
Patient: It was in July 2007.
Doctor: And what did the chest radiographs indicate at that time?
Patient: They showed abnormalities again. There was a mass in my right thoracic wall and right pleural effusion.
Doctor: I see. And then, what happened next?
Patient: I was referred to a hospital for a close examination.
Doctor: Okay. And what did the CT scans show?
Patient: They showed a small amount of pleural effusion on the right side and masses in the right anterior mediastinum and anterior and lateral thoracic regions.
Doctor: I see. And then, what was done next?
Patient: A percutaneous pleural needle biopsy was performed for the mass of the right lateral chest wall.
Doctor: And what was the result of the needle biopsy?
Patient: The diagnosis was pleural mesothelioma.
Doctor: I see. And what were the pathological findings?
Patient: The pathologist described the pathological findings as epithelioid mesothelioma with edematous stroma and intracytoplasmic mucinous vacuoles.
Doctor: I see. And then, what happened next?
Patient: The clinician recommended anticancer drug treatment, but I didn't want to go through with it, so I was just followed up without treatment.
Doctor: Alright. And how have you been feeling lately?
Patient: I started experiencing dyspnea in the middle of May 2010.
Doctor: I see. And did you have any recent chest radiographs taken?
Patient: Yes, I did. It was taken in April 2008.
Doctor: And what did the chest radiographs show?
Patient: There were masses observed in the area corresponding to the right lower lung field's peripheries and the right lateral chest wall.
ideal_response:
The patient was an 82-year-old female with dyspnea as the primary complaint. She had no particular past or familial history. She used to be a nurse (until the age of 72 years) and had no history of occupational asbestos exposure. There was also no history of residence in an asbestos-contaminated environment.
Regarding the history of the present illness, she presented with abnormal chest radiographs (a) during a community health screening in July 2006. Still, she left the findings unattended because of the absence of symptoms. On a retrospective review of the plain chest radiographs taken one year before, in July 2005, the right costophrenic angle was already blunted. The plain chest radiographs taken during the community health screening in July 2007 indicated abnormalities again (b). Patient: Hmm.
Doctor: Did you have any surgery on your left elbow before?
Patient: Yes, I had a supracondylar humerus fracture with intercondylar extension and it was treated with olecrenon osteotomy and medial and lateral column plating.

Doctor: Okay. And did you have any problems after the surgery?

Doctor: Great. And what about your serology for HIV1 and HIV 2?
Patient: My serology was negative for HIV1 and HIV 2.

Patient: Okay.
Doctor: The excision of bursa will be done and the material with the cyst wall and synovium will be sent for culture and histopathology.

Doctor: Hello, how are you feeling today? I see that you presented to our office in 2017 with complaints of chronic left knee pain. Can you tell me more about your symptoms?
Patient: Yes, I have been experiencing left knee pain for years and it's been getting worse with movements.
Doctor: I see. Did you have any previous surgeries for this condition?
Patient: Yes, I had multiple osteochondroma removal surgeries in my left knee, lumbar spine, and left foot at an outside institution. I also had a left hip arthroplasty with refractory numbness and tingling of the leg. 
Doctor: I see. Your electronic medical record from the outside institution indicated a past medical history of diabetes, hyperlipidemia, and hereditary multiple exostosis. We will need to keep an eye on those conditions. 
Patient: Okay.
Doctor: We will need to take some Baseline X-rays of your knee to see if there are any osteoarthritic changes. 
Patient: Sure.
Doctor: The X-rays showed osteoarthritic changes with significant osteochondroma formation. However, arthroplasty was not recommended at that time because of your young age and your left lower extremity being distally neurovascular intact. 
Patient: Okay.
Doctor: I understand that you were adamant about having your knee replaced and were referred to a specialist at an outside institution where an arthroplasty of the left knee was performed. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: The follow-up radiographs showed good alignment of a Smith & Nephew posterior stabilized prosthesis without subsidence. However, you returned 3 months later with continued limited active and passive range of motion. 
Patient: Yes, that's right. 
Doctor: It was decided to perform manipulation under anesthesia followed by 6 weeks of physical therapy which improved your range of motion to 110° flexion. 
Patient: Okay.
Doctor: However, you continue to have limited range of motion of your left knee with flexion to 90°. The large posteriorly projecting osteochondroma of your left tibia continues to be asymptomatic and painless, and therefore, it was decided not to perform surgical interventions at this time. Patient: The arthroplasty helped with the pain, but I still have limited range of motion. 
Doctor: I understand. We will need to continue monitoring your knee and consider other treatment options if necessary. Do you have any other questions or concerns? 
Patient: No, I think that covers everything. 
Doctor: Alright, we will schedule a follow-up appointment to check on your progress. Thank you for coming in today.

Doctor: Good morning, what brings you here today?
Patient: I have been experiencing pain and swelling in my left hand for the past two months.
Doctor: Okay, can you describe the swelling in more detail?
Patient: It's on the thenar eminence and the proximal aspect of my thumb.
Doctor: Hmm, did you have any trauma prior to the development of the swelling?
Patient: No, I didn't have any history of trauma.
Doctor: I see. And was the swelling progressive in nature?
Patient: Yes, it was getting bigger and it was painful when I move my hand.
Doctor: Did you develop any other swellings in your body?
Patient: Yes, I also developed multiple swellings in my cervical region.
Doctor: That's interesting. Do you have any past history of tuberculosis or exposure to tuberculous contact?
Patient: No, I don't have any history of tuberculosis or exposure to tuberculous contact.
Doctor: Okay, did you experience any associated symptoms like loss of appetite, weight loss or any evening rise of temperature?
Patient: No, I didn't have any of those symptoms.
Doctor: I see. We did a radiograph of your hand and it showed a pathological fracture of the base of the 1st metacarpal along with a lytic lesion.
Patient: Hmm, what does that mean?
Doctor: It means that there is a fracture in your hand and a lytic lesion, which is a type of bone lesion that can be caused by a number of things, including a pyogenic infection, tuberculous osteomyelitis or malignancy.
Patient: Oh, okay.
Doctor: We also did an ultrasound and it revealed the presence of an abscess.
Patient: What's an abscess?
Doctor: An abscess is a collection of pus that has accumulated in a tissue or organ.
Patient: Oh, okay.
Doctor: And we did an MRI scan and it showed a large heterogeneous lesion at the 1st carpo-metacarpal joint space along with joint space widening.
Patient: What does that mean?
Doctor: It means that there is a lesion in your joint space that is most likely due to an infective etiology.
Patient: Oh, okay.
Doctor: We performed surgery on you to drain the abscess and debride the infected tissue. We also removed the fragment at the base of the 1st metacarpal and sent it for biopsy and culture sensitivity.
Patient: What happened after the removal of the fragment?
Doctor: After the removal of the fragment, the joint was unstable, so we had to stabilize it with a kirschner wire.
Patient: Okay, what do I need to do now?
Doctor: You need to come back for follow-up appointments and physical therapy to help your hand recover.

She did not have history of any trauma prior to the development of swelling. The swelling was noticed two months ago and was progressive in nature and was painful on movements []. She simultaneously developed multiple swellings in the cervical region which most likely pointed towards cervical lympadenopathy []. She didn’t have any past history of tuberculosis or exposure to tuberculous contact. She did not have any associated symptoms like loss of appetite, weight loss or any evening rise of temperature.
A plain radiograph of the patient was taken which showed pathological fracture of the base of 1st metacarpal along with lytic lesion at the base of the 1st metacarpal with haziness of the surrounding soft tissue []. On x-ray we came to a provisional differential diagnosis of pathological fracture secondary to a pyogenic infection, tuberculous osteomyelitis or soft tissue swelling, malignancy. An ultrasound revealed presence of an abscess. The USG was done to rule out any malignant involvement of the soft-tissue []. An MRI scan showed a large heterogeneous lesion at the 1st carpo-metacarpal joint space along with joint space widening []. The MRI scan suggested an abscess like picture most likely due to infective etiology and less likely to be neoplastic lesion.
She was then posted for drainage of abscess and debridment with stabilization of the fracture fragment. Intra-operatively we found thick caseous material within the soft tissue and the fragment at base of the 1st metacarpal was freely mobile similar to a loose body []. It was not possible to fix that fragment as it looked infected on gross inspection and hence it was removed and sent for biopsy and culture sensitivity along with the surrounding soft-tissue. We also found that after removal of the fragment the joint was unstable and hence a kirschner wire was passed through the 1st carpo

Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: I see. And in order to determine if the multiple enlarged lymph nodes within the small bowel mesentery were involved by cancer, individual lymph nodes were removed and subjected to histopathologic study by permanent sections at a later time, correct?

In the previous 2 months the neck mass had been rapidly growing in size. Medical history included a cerebral trauma owing to a car accident, depression treated with fluoxetine and uterine fibroma. The patient had not been previously exposed to radiation or other known carcinogens. Familiar medical history was negative for thyroid gland or neoplastic diseases. Physical examination revealed a painless well-demarcated mass of about 6 cm localized in the midline of the neck above the thyroid gland covered by skin without any signs of inflammation and/or trauma. The thyroid gland was apparently normal in size and consistence and no significant cervical adenopathy was found at physical examination. At entry serum chemistry tests, electrocardiagram and chest X-rays were normal. A neck ultrasonography identified a 4 cm cyst above a slightly enlarged thyroid gland without any significant alteration. A Sistrunk surgical procedure was then performed and a mass of 5 cm was removed including the entire duct from the gland to the level of the foramen cecum and the middle portion of the hyoid bone (Figure ). A small 1 cm wide lymph node close to the cyst was also surgically removed. Post-operative follow-up was uneventful.
Gross examination of the surgical specimen showed a cystic mass of about 3 cm in greatest dimension with a smooth external surface. Microscopic examination showed the presence of papillary carcinoma with small areas of follicular carcinoma inside the thyroglossal duct cyst and metastatic disease in the adjacent lymph node. Further staging with neck sonogram showed an enlarged thyroid gland with a pattern suspicious for neoplastic disease subsequently confirmed by fine-needle aspiration biopsy. CT scan failed to identify distant metastatic disease. The patient underwent total nerve-sparing thyroidectomy with neck lymphoadenectomy. No significant post-surgical complications were recorded and the surgical wound healed regularly. Pathological examination showed a multinodular, moderately differentiated

prompt:
You are a helpful assistant that can generate a clinical note from a conversation transcript between a patient and a doctor. 

The conversation transcript is given below: 

Doctor: Good afternoon, sir. How are you feeling today?
Patient: I'm feeling okay, doctor.
Doctor: That's good to hear. I understand you were found to have space-occupying lesions on both your kidneys during a routine physical examination.
Patient: Hmm, yes. That's why I came to your hospital for diagnosis and treatment.
Doctor: I see. We did some laboratory tests, including those for thyroid function, and all the results are within normal ranges.
Patient: Okay.
Doctor: And we also performed an abdominal computed tomography scan, which revealed a relatively homogeneously enhancing mass in the lower pole of your left kidney. It measures 4 cm in its greatest dimension. 
Patient: Hmm, okay.
Doctor: And there is also a cystic lesion in your right kidney. We surgically removed part of the wall of the right renal cyst for intraoperative pathological examination.
Patient: Yes, I remember.
Doctor: The Histology showed cells arranged in a single or multiple layers, which could be seen in some areas of the cyst wall. But cellular atypia, nucleoli, and mitosis were not obvious.
Patient: Hmm, okay.
Doctor: We also observed obvious necrosis and hemorrhage in another area, and the fibrous tissue in the cyst wall was perforated. Some suspicious infiltrating glands could also be seen in the fibrous stroma.
Patient: I see.
Doctor: Based on these findings, we suspected cystic renal cell carcinoma. To preserve some kidney function, you underwent partial nephrectomy of the right kidney with nephron preservation and left radical nephrectomy.
Patient: Yes, I remember that.
Doctor: According to the postoperative pathology examination, we observed follicular architecture with micro- and macrofollicles containing eosinophilic secretions or colloid-like material in another area of the right renal cyst wall.
Patient: Hmm, okay.
Doctor: The follicular cells contained moderate eosinophilic cytoplasm and round nuclei. The left renal tumor was a typical clear cell renal cell carcinoma.
Patient: Hmm, I see.
Doctor: And the immunohistochemistry revealed that the tumor cells of the right kidney tumor were positive for cytokeratin 7 and paired Box 2 but were negative for transcription termination factor 1, thyroglobulin, and synaptophysin.
Patient: Hmm, okay.
Doctor: There was no evidence of a mass in the thyroid gland or enlargement of regional lymph nodes on ultrasonography of the neck. Therefore, the right renal tumor was finally diagnosed as thyroid-like follicular renal cell carcinoma with cystic changes, while the left kidney tumor was diagnosed as clear cell renal cell carcinoma.
Patient: Hmm, I understand.
Doctor: You didn't receive postoperative adjuvant therapy.
Patient: No, I didn't.
Doctor: Okay, I think that's all the information I need for now. If you have any questions or concerns, please feel free to ask.
Patient: No, I'm good for now. Thank you, doctor.
ideal_response: The patient is a 47-year-old male. He was found to have space-occupying lesions on both kidneys during routine physical examination and presented to our hospital for diagnosis and treatment. Laboratory test results including those for thyroid function were within normal ranges. Abdominal computed tomography revealed a relatively homogeneously enhancing mass in the lower pole of the left kidney (4 cm in its greatest dimension) and a cystic lesion in the right kidney (). Part of the wall of the right renal cyst was surgically removed, and intraoperative pathological examination was performed. Histology showed cells arranged in a single or multiple layers, which could be seen in some areas of the cyst wall. Cellular atypia, nucleoli, and mitosis were not obvious (). Obvious necrosis and hemorrhage could be seen in another area, and the fibrous tissue in the cyst wall was perforated; some suspicious infiltrating glands could also be seen in the fibrous stroma (). We suspected cystic renal cell carcinoma. To preserve some kidney function, the patient underwent partial nephrectomy of the right kidney with nephron preservation and left radical nephrectomy. According to the postoperative pathology examination, we observed follicular architecture with micro- and macrofollicles containing eosinophilic secretions or colloid-like material in another area of the right renal cyst wall (). The follicular cells contained moderate eosinophilic cytoplasm and round nuclei (). The left renal tumor was a typical clear cell renal cell carcinoma (). Immunohistochemistry revealed that the tumor cells of the right kidney tumor were positive for cytokeratin 7 (CK7) () and paired Box 2 (PAX2) () but were negative for transcription termination factor 1 (TTF1) (), thyroglobulin (TG), and synaptophysin (Syn). There was no evidence of a mass in the thyroid gland or enlargement of regional lymph nodes on ultrasonography of the neck. Therefore, the right renal tumor was finally diagnosed as thyroid-like follicular renal cell carcinoma with cystic changes, while the left kidney tumor was diagnosed as clear cell renal cell carcinoma. The patient did not receive postoperative adjuvant

prompt:
You are a helpful assistant that can generate a clinical note from a conversation transcript between a patient and a doctor. 

The conversation transcript is given below: 

Doctor: Good morning, how are you feeling today?
Patient: Good morning, I'm feeling okay.
Doctor: Can you tell me what brings you here today?
Patient: Yes, I have been experiencing sleep onset insomnia for the past 20 days.
Doctor: I see. What was the cause of your insomnia?
Patient: I bought an over the counter medication tablet ZPD 10 mg after having seen my consultant prescribe the same for insomnia.
Doctor: Okay, and what happened after you took the tablet?
Patient: After consuming a 10 mg tablet of ZPD, I sat on the floor mat along with another colleague of mine for studying till I felt sleepy. About 30 minutes later, I reported that the letters appeared to be shaking and going out of order.
Doctor: Hmm, that sounds unusual. What happened next?
Patient: Few minutes later, I raised my hand to alarm that I was about to sink.
Doctor: I see. Can you describe the experience you had after that?
Patient: I felt like I was in a lake and surrounded by water, floating with my friend on a boat and my body was bouncing up and down. The surrounding had assumed a bright orange hue. I was very frightened.
Doctor: That sounds scary. What did your friend do?
Patient: My friend tried to convince me that no such thing was occurring and took me to the TV room.
Doctor: I see. And what happened then?
Patient: I reported that the characters were coming out of the TV (that was switched off) and I tried to approach them. I was talking to them as if they were in the room and I was unable to delineate with my surroundings, although I was oriented to time and to my friend.
Doctor: That's interesting. Was there any report of unusual experience in touch, pain, temperature or other modality?
Patient: No, there was no report of unusual experience in touch, pain, temperature or other modality.
Doctor: Okay, I understand. What happened next?
Patient: My friend convinced me and took me to bed and I fell asleep after 10 minutes.
Doctor: I see. And what happened the next morning?
Patient: The next morning I had memories of the same and could recall the events and I consulted the physician.
Doctor: Okay, that's good. Can you tell me about your medical history? Are you married?
Patient: No, I'm an unmarried 22-year-old female, a third-year medical student with nil significant family history and a well-adjusted premorbid personality.
Doctor: I see. And what happened during the assessment?
Patient: On assessment, there was no evidence of physical illness.
Doctor: I understand. Based on your symptoms, I would like to run some tests to make sure everything is okay.
Doctor: Can you follow up with me in a week?
Patient: Yes, of course.
Doctor: Great. If you have any other symptoms, don't hesitate to come back and see me.
Patient: Okay, thank you.
Doctor: You're welcome. Have a good day.
Patient: You too.
ideal_response:
A 22 year old unmarried female, a third year medical student with nil significant family history and a well adjusted premorbid personality had been experiencing sleep onset insomnia for twenty days prior to her exams. She would not sleep till 1 AM and would get up late in the morning. She bought over the counter medication tablet ZPD 10 mg after having seen her consultant prescribe the same for insomnia. After consuming a 10 mg tablet of ZPD, she sat on the floor mat along with another colleague of hers for studying till she felt sleepy. About 30 minutes later she complained to her friend that the letters appeared to be shaking and going out of order. She reported that words no longer stayed in a straight line but appeared in disarray. Few minutes later she raised her hand to alarm that she was about to sink. Following this she had a very weird experience.
She felt to be in a lake and surrounded by water; floating with her friend on a boat and her body was bouncing up and down and the surrounding had assumed a bright orange hue. She was very frightened, held her friend asking for help and requesting to park at lakeside.
They stopped studying and her friend tried to convince that no such thing is occurring, and took her to TV room. She reported that the characters are coming out of the TV (that was switched off) and she tried to approach them; was talking to them as if they were in their room and unable to delineate with her surroundings though she was oriented to time and to her friend. There was no report of unusual experience in touch, pain, temperature or other modality. The friend convinced her and took her to bed and she fell asleep after 10 minutes. The next morning she had memories of the same and could recollect the events and consulted the physician. On assessment there was no evidence of physical illness

prompt:
You are a helpful assistant that can generate a clinical note from a conversation transcript between a patient and a doctor. 

The conversation transcript is given below: 

Doctor: Hi, how are you feeling today?
Patient: I've been having some pain in my abdomen.
Doctor: Can you tell me more about the pain? When did it start?
Patient: It started back in November of 2015. I was diagnosed with a large uterine fibroid and had a myomectomy.
Doctor: I see. Were there any malignancies associated with the specimens recovered?
Patient: No, there were no malignancies found.
Doctor: Have you noticed any other changes or symptoms since then?
Patient: Yes, in December of 2016 I started feeling abdominal pain again and noticed a mass on the right side during a physical examination.
Doctor: Did you have any tests done at that time?
Patient: Yes, I had a colonoscopy and biopsy, which showed a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the caecum.
Doctor: I see. And what happened after that?
Patient: A CT scan was performed in December of 2016, which showed the primary colon malignancy along with bilateral ovarian metastases.
Doctor: Did you have any further tests or treatments?
Patient: Yes, I had a percutaneous biopsy of the right ovarian mass, which showed a colonic primary. From December of 2016 through December of 2017, I was on chemotherapy.
Doctor: What kind of chemotherapy were you on?
Patient: Initially, I was treated with FOLFOX, but after four cycles, I had neuropathy and the oxaliplatin was stopped. I was maintained on 5-fluorouracil and bevacizumab.
Doctor: I see. And how did that go?
Patient: In December of 2017, a CT scan showed marked regression of the primary tumor. It was no longer visible, but multiple lymph nodes within the mesentery of the distal small bowel were enlarged.
Doctor: And then what happened?
Patient: A pelvic mass showed that the right ovary had increased in size to 15 cm in greatest diameter, despite the fact that the primary caecal malignancy was no longer visible by CT. Over approximately one month, I became rapidly more symptomatic with abdominal distention from ascites and an expanding right ovarian mass.
Doctor: I see. And what did you do then?
Patient: On February 1, 2018, I underwent cytoreductive surgery and HIPEC in a specialized center for management of peritoneal metastases.
Doctor: What kind of surgery did you have?
Patient: I underwent a greater omentectomy, hysterectomy, bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, complete pelvic peritonectomy, right colon resection, and small bowel resection.
Doctor: And what kind of treatment did you receive?
Patient: I received HIPEC with mitomycin C and doxorubicin, along with systemic fluorouracil.
Doctor: I see. And were there any complications?
Patient: In order to determine if the multiple enlarged lymph nodes within the small bowel mesentery were involved by cancer, individual lymph nodes were removed and subjected to histopathologic study by permanent sections at a later time.
Doctor: I see. Well, it sounds like you've been through a lot. You'll need to come in for follow-up appointments to make sure everything is healing properly.
ideal_response:
A 49 year old woman complained of abdominal pain in November of 2015 with diagnosis of large uterine fibroid, a myomectomy from within the uterus was performed. No malignancy was associated with the specimens recovered. In December of 2016, the abdominal pain persisted and a mass was palpable on physical examination in the mid-abdomen on the right. Colonoscopy was performed and biopsy showed a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the caecum.
CT was performed in December of 2016 and the primary right colon malignancy along with bilateral ovarian metastases were imaged. Percutaneous biopsy of the right ovarian mass showed well differentiated adenocarcinoma consistent with a colonic primary. From December of 2016 through December of 2017, the patient was maintained on chemotherapy. Initially, she was treated with FOLFOX. After four cycles, because of neuropathy, the oxaliplatin was stopped. The patient was maintained on 5-fluorouracil and bevacizumab.
In December of 2017, a CT documented marked regression of the primary tumor. It was not visible by CT. However, multiple lymph nodes within the mesentery of the distal small bowel were enlarged. Also by CT a pelvic mass showed that the right ovary had increased in size to 15 cm in greatest diameter despite the fact that the primary caecal malignancy was no longer visible by CT.
Over approximately one month the patient became rapidly more symptomatic with abdominal distention from ascites and an expanding right ovarian mass. On February 1, 2018 the patient underwent cytoreductive surgery and HIPEC in a specialized center for management of peritoneal metastases. At the time of surgery she underwent a greater omentectomy, hysterectomy, bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, complete pelvic peritonectomy, right colon resection, and small bowel resection. She received HIPEC with mitomycin C and doxorubicin with systemic fluorouracil. In order to determine if the multiple enlarged lymph nodes within the small bowel mesentery were involved by cancer, individual lymph nodes were removed and subjected to histopathologic study by permanent sections at a later time. A portion of each of these lymph nodes was sent

prompt:
You are a helpful assistant that can generate a clinical note from a conversation transcript between a patient and a doctor. 

The conversation transcript is given below: 

Doctor: Hi there, how are you feeling today?
Patient: I'm feeling okay, just a little tired.
Doctor: I see here in your medical history that you've been experiencing increasing fatigue since 2014. Can you tell me more about that?
Patient: Yeah, it started off as just feeling a little tired, but it's been getting worse over time.
Doctor: Have you experienced any other symptoms, like left lower quadrant pain?
Patient: Yes, the pain has been getting more severe over time as well.
Doctor: I see. Did you go to the emergency room for this pain?
Patient: Yes, I did.
Doctor: Okay, and on February 19th, you had a CT scan that showed an infiltrate into the greater omentum and multiple nodules associated with small bowel mesentery. There was no ascites. Masses were present on both the right and left ovaries. 
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: On March 14th, you had an operation where multiple biopsies were taken. Your left ovary and appendix were removed and pathology showed a mature cystic teratoma and extensive malignant peritoneal mesothelioma. Do you remember that?
Patient: Yes, I remember that.
Doctor: I see. And on May 2nd of this year, you had another CT scan that showed malignant peritoneal mesothelioma infiltrating the omentum and accumulating as a diffuse mass in the pelvis. The small bowel mesentery showed multiple prominent lymph nodes. 
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: Okay, and on May 3rd, you had a surgery to remove the malignant peritoneal mesothelioma along with other procedures. 
Patient: Yes, that's right.
Doctor: During that surgery, HIPEC was performed with cisplatin, doxorubicin, and systemic ifosfamide with Mesna. A layer of tumor from large and small bowel surfaces was removed along with large and small bowel mesenteric surfaces. Six mesenteric lymph nodes were harvested during the HIPEC chemotherapy. 
Patient: Okay.
Doctor: The results of the doxorubicin within blood, peritoneal fluid, lymph nodes, and tumor were analyzed. The area under the curve ratio of lymph node doxorubicin to plasma doxorubicin was 30. The area under the curve ratio of tumor nodules to plasma was... 
Patient: Can you explain what that means?
Doctor: Sure. Basically, the results indicate that there was a high concentration of doxorubicin in the lymph nodes and tumor, which is a good thing. It suggests that the chemotherapy was effective in treating the cancer. 
Patient: Okay, I understand.
Doctor: Going forward, we'll need to continue monitoring your condition and potentially do more treatments if necessary. Do you have any questions for me?
Patient: No, I think I understand. 
Doctor: Okay. It may also be important to involve your family in your care going forward. We can discuss that more in the future.
ideal_response:
This 35 year old woman began noticing increasing fatigue in 2014. The fatigue and left lower quadrant pain became increasingly severe so that she went an emergency room. On 19 February 2018, a CT scan was performed that showed an infiltrate into the greater omentum and multiple nodules associated with small bowel mesentery. There was no ascites. Masses were present on both the right and left ovaries. On 14 March 2018, she was taken to the operating room where multiple biopsies were taken. Her left ovary and appendix were removed. Pathology showed a mature cystic teratoma and extensive malignant peritoneal mesothelioma. Multiple biopsies from omentum, surface of uterus, peritoneum from the abdominal wall, and peritoneum from the small bowel showed malignant peritoneal mesothelioma.
Repeat CT on 2 May 2018 showed malignant peritoneal mesothelioma infiltrating the omentum and accumulating as a diffuse mass in the pelvis. The small bowel mesentery showed multiple prominent lymph nodes. For definitive treatment of her malignant peritoneal mesothelioma, the patient was taken back to the operating room on 3 May 2018. At that time she had a greater and lesser omentectomy, cholecystectomy, pelvic peritonectomy with hysterectomy and right oophorectomy along with cytoreductive surgery of the small and large bowel surfaces. HIPEC was performed with cisplatin, doxorubicin, and systemic ifosfamide with Mesna (2-Mercaptoethanesulfonic acid sodium). prompt:
You are a helpful assistant that can generate a clinical note from a conversation transcript between a patient and a doctor. 

The conversation transcript is given below: 

Doctor: Good morning, what brings you to the Periodontology Department today?
Patient: Good morning, doctor. I have been experiencing dull pain on my left side of the lower jaw and neck for the past 2 years.
Doctor: Hmm, I see. Can you describe the pain for me?
Patient: The pain is generalized and feels like it's coming from my gums and deep within my lower jaw. It's intermittent and has been happening 2-3 times in a row for the past 3 months. It's gotten worse over the past 15 days and is worse when I bend forward or flex my neck.
Doctor: Okay, I understand. Do you have any other symptoms?
Patient: Yes, I have loose teeth in my mouth but they don't hurt.
Doctor: Alright. Can you tell me about your medical history?
Patient: I have hypertension and I take atenolol 10 mg once a day for it. I also have type-II diabetes and take glibenclamide 500 mg once a day for it.
Doctor: I see. Do you have any history of past trauma?
Patient: No, I don't.
Doctor: Alright. Let's take a look at your mouth. [Examines the patient's mouth] I don't see any abnormalities with your temperomandibular joint and your regional lymph nodes are not palpable. However, your submandibular areas are tender on palpation bilaterally. You have adequate mouth opening, but you said you feel irritation in your throat when you open your mouth wide.
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: I see plaque and calculus in your mouth. There is also generalized bleeding on probing and deep periodontal pockets indicating generalized chronic periodontitis. The pocket formation is more in your maxillary arch than in your mandibular arch. Your maxillary right first and second premolars show Miller's Grade III mobility.
Patient: Okay.
Doctor: Based on these clinical findings, I diagnose you with generalized chronic periodontitis. I would like to take an orthopantomogram (OPG) to see the extent of the problem. The OPG will show us the alveolar bone loss and the presence of any bone destruction.
Patient: Alright.
Doctor: [After taking the OPG] The OPG shows that you have generalized alveolar bone loss and your mandibular right first molar shows advanced periapical bone destruction. Your maxillary third molars and your mandibular right third molar are impacted.
Patient: Okay.
Doctor: I would also like to take a lateral cephalogram to ascertain the presence and extent of any elongated styloid processes.
Patient: Alright.
Doctor: [After taking the cephalogram] The cephalogram shows that you have bilateral elongated styloid processes.
Patient: What does that mean?
Doctor: It means that the bones in your neck are longer than normal and may be causing some of your symptoms. We will need to treat your periodontitis and monitor your elongated styloid processes. I will give you some instructions on how to take care of your teeth and gums. We will also schedule a follow-up appointment in three months to see how you're doing.
Patient: Alright, thank you, doctor.
ideal_response:
A 50-year-old female reported to the Periodontology Department of our College with a complaint of dull pain on her left side of the lower jaw, which radiated to her neck since 2 years. The pain was generalized in nature and she felt it to be arising from the gums and deep within the lower jaw. It was intermittent in nature, recurring 2–3 times in succession in the past 3 months and had worsened for the past 15 days. It aggravated on bending forwards and flexing the neck. She also complained of loose teeth in her mouth but said the teeth were not hurting. Medical history revealed that the patient had hypertension and was on tab atenolol 10 mg once daily for the past 2 years. She was also a diagnosed case of type-II diabetes mellitus (fasting blood glucose level was 260 mg/dL) and was on oral hypoglycemic, tablet glibenclamide 500 mg once daily. The patient gave no history of any past trauma.
On extraoral examination, no abnormalities were detected with the temperomandibular joint and the regional lymph nodes were not palpable. However, the submandibular areas were tender on palpation bilaterally. Mouth opening was adequate, but patient reported irritation in her throat on opening the mouth wide. Intra-oral examination revealed presence of plaque and calculus. There was generalized bleeding on probing and deep periodontal pockets indicating generalized chronic periodontitis and the pocket formation were more in the maxillary than in the mandibular arch. The maxillary right first and second premolars showed Miller's Grade III mobility. Based on these clinical findings the case was diagnosed as generalized chronic periodontitis. An orthopantomogram (OPG) was taken, which revealed generalized alveolar bone loss and the mandibular right first molar showed advanced periapical bone destruction. Both the maxillary third molars and the mandibular right third molar were impacted. The OPG also revealed the presence of bilateral elongated styloid processes []. A lateral cephalogram was also taken to ascertain the presence and extent of the elongated styloid process []. However

prompt:
You are a helpful assistant that can generate a clinical note from a conversation transcript between a patient and a doctor. 

The conversation transcript is given below: 

Doctor: Good morning, what brings you here today?
Patient: I have been having pain and numbness in my legs for the past two months.
Doctor: Hmm, okay. Can you tell me a little bit more about your symptoms?
Patient: Sure. The pain is on the outer border of both my legs and the numbness is on the top of my feet and big toes. The pain gets worse when I walk or run and it feels better when I elevate my legs.
Doctor: I see. And is there anything that makes the pain worse?
Patient: Yes, walking and running makes it worse. I have to stop and rest after 30 minutes of walking because of the pain.
Doctor: Okay, thank you for that information. Do you have a history of any trauma or surgery to your lower limbs or back problems?
Patient: No, there is no history of that.
Doctor: Alright. And have you experienced any severe weight loss recently?
Patient: Yes, I lost 30 kg in the past six months.
Doctor: I see. And were you diagnosed with anorexia nervosa?
Patient: Yes, I was.
Doctor: Alright. During the physical examination, we found some tender points on the outer surface of your legs, about 11 cm from the ankle joint. And the Tinel sign was positive bilaterally.
Patient: Hmm, okay.
Doctor: We also found some sensory deficits on the top of both your big toes, but no muscle weakness or abnormal reflexes.
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: And after examining your lumbar spine and lower limbs, we didn't find any clinical abnormalities in the joints. And there was no suspicion of nerve root compression at the level of the lumbar spine or nerve entrapment at the neck of the fibula.
Patient: Okay.
Doctor: Our radiographic examination of your lumbar spine, legs, and feet were normal. But our EMG studies showed that you have bilateral entrapment neuropathy of the SPN, proximal to the ankle joint. And there was no abnormality of the common peroneal nerves or of the proximal nerve roots.
Patient: Hmm, okay.
Doctor: After preoperative assessment, we admitted you for surgical treatment with the diagnosis of SPN entrapment. The operation was done under general anaesthesia, using a pneumatic tourniquet.
Patient: Okay.
Doctor: During the operation, we found adhesions of both SPNs to the fascia with perineural fibrosis. So we carefully dissected the nerves and performed neurolysis to free the nerves. The nerves were freed distally and proximally by splitting.
Patient: Okay, I understand.
Doctor: Great. You should start feeling better soon. Please come back to see me in two weeks for a follow-up appointment.
Patient: Okay, thank you doctor.
ideal_response:
A 20-year-old, female university student presented to our outpatient orthopaedic clinic with a two month history of vague pain on the outer border of both legs, and numbness over the dorsum of the feet and big toes. Her symptoms were exacerbated by walking and running and partially relieved by elevation. She had to stop to rest after 30 minutes of walking because of intolerable pain.
There was neither history of trauma or surgery to the lower limb nor history of lower back problems. There was, however, a history of severe weight loss of (30 kg) during the previous six months and the patient was diagnosed with anorexia nervosa using criteria from the American Psychiatric Association's Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-IV-TR) and the World Health Organization's International Statistical Classification of Diseases and Related Health Problems (ICD).
Physical examination revealed bilateral tender points approximately 11 cm proximal to the ankle joint on the outer surface of the leg, Tinel sign was also positive bilaterally. There were sensory deficits on the dorsum of both big toes but no muscle weakness or abnormal reflexes.
Examination of the lumbar spine and lower limbs revealed no clinical abnormalities in the joints and there was neither suspicion of nerve root compression at the level of the lumbar spine nor nerve entrapment at the neck of the fibula.
Radiographic examination of the lumbar spine, legs and feet were normal and EMG studies were positive for bilateral entrapment neuropathy of the SPN proximal to the ankle joint with no abnormality of the common peroneal nerves or of the proximal nerve roots.
After preoperative assessment, the patient was admitted for surgical treatment with the diagnosis of SPN entrapment. The operation was done under general anaesthesia, using pneumatic tourniquet. Bilateral explorations of the site of tenderness revealed adhesions of both SPNs to the fascia with perineural fibrosis. Careful dissections were done to free the nerves and neurolysis was successfully performed (Figure ). The nerves were freed distally and proximally by splitting

prompt:
You are a helpful assistant that can generate a clinical note from a conversation transcript between a patient and a doctor. 

The conversation transcript is given below: 

Doctor: Good morning, what brings you here today?
Patient: I came because I have a high-grade fever, myalgia, and shortness of breath.
Doctor: Hmm, I see. And when did you first start experiencing these symptoms?
Patient: It was around the 16th of May.
Doctor: Okay. And did you get tested for COVID-19?
Patient: Yes, I did, and I tested positive.
Doctor: I see. So, when were you admitted to the hospital?
Patient: I was admitted two days after I tested positive.
Doctor: And how was your condition when you were admitted?
Patient: My condition was bad. I had severe pneumonia, and I required mechanical ventilation support.
Doctor: I see. And did you try any other forms of support before mechanical ventilation?
Patient: Yes, I did. I was in a prone position, but it didn't help.
Doctor: Okay. So, what medications were you started on?
Patient: I was given azithromycin 500 mg intravenous, tocilizumab 600 mg intravenous single dose, hydroxychloroquine 400 mg tablets once a day, and methylprednisolone 40 mg twice daily.
Doctor: And how did your condition change after taking these medications?
Patient: Unfortunately, I developed acute kidney injury, and I needed renal replacement therapy.
Doctor: I see. And what form of renal replacement therapy did you receive?
Patient: I received sustained low-efficiency dialysis through a right femoral vein central line.
Doctor: And did you experience any complications during the dialysis?
Patient: Yes, I did. I developed deep vein thrombosis on the same side of the hemodialysis catheter.
Doctor: I see. And what was done to prevent this from happening again?
Patient: I was given prophylaxis with low molecular heparin.
Doctor: Okay. And did you have any issues with the central line after that?
Patient: Yes, I did. The venous pressure was high, which indicates possible arterial flow.
Doctor: I see. And what was done to resolve this issue?
Patient: Another line was inserted on the right internal jugular using ultrasound guidance, and it worked well.
Doctor: Okay. And what happened to the left internal jugular catheter?
Patient: It was removed, and pressure dressing was applied.
Doctor: I see. And did you experience any other complications after that?
Patient: Yes, I did. I developed left upper arm and supraclavicular swelling, and my hemoglobin dropped by 4-5 to 5 g from the initial 9.5 g.
Doctor: I see. And what was done to stabilize you?
Patient: I was stabilized by fluid resuscitation and blood transfusion.
Doctor: And was there any sign of active bleeding?
Patient: No, there wasn't. No melena or any sign of active bleeding was identified.
Doctor: I see. And when were you extubated?
Patient: I was extubated on the 1st of June.
Doctor: And how was your breathing after that?
Patient: I was breathing well, but I had retrosternal chest pain with an elevated troponin level.
Doctor: I see. And what was the diagnosis for the chest pain?
Patient: It was diagnosed as myocardial infarction type II, and it was treated conservatively.
Doctor: I see. And did you experience any other symptoms after that?
Patient: Yes, I did. I had left shoulder pain and was unable to move my left arm.
Doctor: I see. And what was done about that?

Doctor: Good morning, I am Dr. X. How are you feeling today?
Patient: Not so good, doctor. I have been having seizures for the past few months.
Doctor: I see. Can you tell me more about your history of epilepsy?
Patient: I have been diagnosed with focal epilepsy for 5 years now. I was on antiepileptic medication and my quality of life had improved.
Doctor: That's great to hear. What kind of antiepileptic medication were you taking?
Patient: I was taking carbamazepine, 1000 mg per day.
Doctor: And how long have you been taking it?
Patient: I have been taking it for 1 year.
Doctor: Okay. And what happened that you were admitted to our tertiary care hospital?
Patient: The seizures recurred once in every 2-3 weeks for the last 3 months. So I was admitted for further management and drug optimization.
Doctor: I understand. Can you tell me about your general physical examination?
Patient: It was normal. There was no history of prior behavioral problems or cognitive deficits.
Doctor: Okay. And is there any family history of psychotic disorder?
Patient: No, there isn't.
Doctor: Alright. I see that your blood investigations for electrolytes, renal function test, thyroid, liver function and other related tests were within normal limits.
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: And your CT scan of the brain showed a left frontal calcified lesion, which is suggestive of cysticercosis.
Patient: Yes, that's what I was told.
Doctor: And the CT brain with contrast showed no further new or active lesions.
Patient: That's right.
Doctor: And your EEG was normal?
Patient: Yes, it was.
Doctor: Okay. And your serum carbamazepine level was 10 μg/ml.
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: In view of your poor seizure control and the serum carbamazepine level reaching the upper limits of normal, we added LEV with an initial dose of 250 mg twice a day.
Patient: Okay.
Doctor: However, by day 3, you developed severe behavioral abnormality characterized by agitation, emotional liability, hostility and depersonalization.
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: You were evaluated by the psychiatrist and were diagnosed with acute psychosis.
Patient: Yes, that's right.
Doctor: And the psychiatric assessment revealed features of depression, mood and thought abnormality, suspicious and withdrawal state with visual hallucination suggestive of psychosis.
Patient: Yes, that's what I was told.
Doctor: And delirium was ruled out as there was no fluctuation in sensorium, focal deficits and meningeal signs.
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: Considering the possibility of drug induced psychosis, LEV was withheld.
Patient: Okay.
Doctor: We will monitor your condition closely and adjust your medication as needed. Please let us know if you have any questions or concerns.
Patient: Thank you, doctor.
ideal_response:
A 52-year-old male epileptic patient was brought to our tertiary care hospital with uncontrolled seizure. He had history of focal epilepsy since 5 years and was on antiepileptic medication. He was on carbamazepine, with a total dose of 1000 mg per day, since 1 year. He was apparently doing alright for some time and his quality of life had improved on carbamazepine. However, the seizures recurred once in every 2-3 weeks for the last 3 months because of which he was admitted in neurology department for further management and drug optimization.
His general physical examination was normal. There was no history of prior behavioral problems or cognitive deficits. There was no family history of psychotic disorder. His blood investigations for electrolytes, renal function test, thyroid, liver function and other related tests were within normal limits. His computed tomography (CT) scan of brain showed left frontal calcified lesion suggestive of cysticercosis. His CT brain with contrast showed no further new or active lesions. His EEG was normal. His serum carbamazepine level was 10 μg/ml.
In view of his poor seizure control and serum carbamazepine level reaching the upper limits of normal, he was added on LEV with an initial dose of 250 mg twice a day and was planned to increase the dose gradually over 2-4 weeks to reach a dose up to a total 1000 mg per day. However, by day 3 the patient developed severe behavioral abnormality characterized by agitation, emotional liability, hostility and depersonalization. He was evaluated by the psychiatrist and was diagnosed as acute psychosis. His mental state examination was normal except for abnormal mood and thoughts. Psychiatric assessment revealed features of depression, mood and thought abnormality, suspicious and withdrawal state with visual hallucination suggestive of psychosis. Delirium was ruled out as there was no fluctuation in sensorium, focal deficits and meningeal signs. As mentioned earlier, the lab investigations were done to rule out metabolic causes of this clinical presentation.
Considering the possibility of drug induced psychosis, LEV was withheld.

Patient: Yes, that's correct.

Patient: No, apart from this illness, I have never been to hospitals for any other medical or surgical condition.

Patient: No, I have never been allergic to the exposed medications.
Doctor: I see. The physical examination showed an emaciated man looking older than his chronological age, appeared pallor but no clinical evidence of jaundice. Abdominal examination was normal. Did the chest examination show any remarkable findings?

prompt:
You are a helpful assistant that can generate a clinical note from a conversation transcript between a patient and a doctor.

Doctor: Good morning, may I know why you were admitted to the General Hospital?
Patient: Good morning, doctor. I was admitted because of frequent urination and burning pain.
Doctor: Hmm, I see. Can you tell me more about your frequent urination?
Patient: Yes, I have been experiencing frequent urination for the past 10 years. I have to go to the bathroom 3 to 4 times every hour, and up to 18 times at night.
Doctor: I understand. This must have had a negative impact on your quality of sleep.
Patient: Yes, it really has.
Doctor: Okay. And what about the pain? Where is it located?
Patient: The pain is located at my episiotomy scar.
Doctor: I see. Have you received any treatment for this before?
Patient: Yes, I have. I received an injection of antibiotics drugs at my work unit's clinic, but it didn't have much effect.
Doctor: Okay. And then?
Patient: Then, I visited the Department of Urology in Beijing. They found a polyp and treated it with laser excision. I also received physical therapy, but my symptoms still didn't improve.
Doctor: I see. And then?
Patient: Then, I had an operation at the site of my episiotomy scar. It was found to be inflammation of muscle tissues at the wound site. I was given antibiotics and external application of estrogen postoperatively. But my pain only got worse, so I visited the Pain Department and was given acesodyne to relieve the pain.
Doctor: I understand. And did you receive any other treatments after that?
Patient: Yes, I did. I sought medical advice and even tried some folk prescriptions, but nothing worked.
Doctor: Okay. And what happened on September 30, 2011?
Patient: On September 30, 2011, I was admitted to the Department of Urology in Beijing again. They performed a routine urine test and found white blood cells throughout the visual field under the microscope. I took antibiotics and estrogen after the examination, but it didn't have any obvious curative effect for 3 to 4 months.
Doctor: I understand. And that's why you came to the TCM Department of General Hospital of the PLA.
Patient: Yes, that's right.
Doctor: Okay, I will examine you now. On TCM observation, you have burning pain. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: Alright. I will prescribe some TCM treatment for you. In the meantime, please continue taking the antibiotics and estrogen.
Patient: Okay, doctor. Thank you.
Doctor: You're welcome. Please come back to see me in a week.
Patient: Okay, doctor. Thank you.

Subsequently, the patient had odynuria and pain at the site of episiotomy scar. The patient visited the clinic of the work unit for intravenous injection of antibiotics drugs, without obvious effect. A few months later, the patient visited the Department of Urology in Beijing. A polyp was observed during urethra examination, which was then treated by laser excision. The symptoms were still not improved after several courses of physical therapy. In November 2002, an operation was carried out at the site of episiotomy scar, and it was found to be inflammation of muscle tissues at wound site after opening. The patient was given antibiotics and external application of estrogen postoperatively. One month after operation, the patient perceived aggravated pain and restless that affected physical activity. Consequently, the patient visited the Pain Department and was provided with acesodyne to relieve pain. However, the symptom of pain was still not totally relieved. Accordingly, the patient sought medical advices even from folk prescription for years, but was not cured. On September 30, 2011, the patient was admitted to the Department of Urology in Beijing. A routine urine test was performed, and white blood cells were found throughout the visual field under the microscope. Simultaneously the patient still took antibiotics and estrogen after the examination, but had no obvious curative effect for 3 to 4 months. On December 7, 2011, the patient sought TCM treatment in TCM Department of General Hospital of the PLA.

prompt:
You are a helpful assistant that can generate a clinical note from a conversation transcript between a patient and a doctor.
