Doctor: Good morning. How can I help you today?
Patient: Good morning, doctor. I have been experiencing pain in my right knee for the past 12 months.
Doctor: I see. Can you describe the pain for me?
Patient: It started as a mild pain, but it has become slightly worse at night.
Doctor: Hmm, do you have any knee effusion or swelling?
Patient: No, I don't have any knee effusion or swelling.
Doctor: Okay. Do you have a definite history of trauma or any medical history of rheumatoid arthritis or other arthritic diseases?
Patient: No, I don't have any history of trauma or any medical history of rheumatoid arthritis or any other arthritic diseases.
Doctor: I see. Did you visit another hospital for the same symptom a year before this presentation?
Patient: Yes, I did.
Doctor: And what did they do for you?
Patient: They performed plain radiography and magnetic resonance imaging of my knee, but the plain radiographs showed normal findings.
Doctor: Hmm, what did the MRI show?
Patient: The MRI showed a widespread signal change in the subchondral bone of the lateral femoral condyle.
Doctor: Okay. And what was the initial diagnosis?
Patient: The initial diagnosis was bone bruise of the lateral femoral condyle.
Doctor: And what was the treatment for that?
Patient: I was treated conservatively using intermittent nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug medication and physical therapy, but it didn't result in pain relief.
Doctor: I see. Can you describe the location of the pain when you presented at our hospital?
Patient: The pain is in the anterolateral aspect of my right knee.
Doctor: Okay. And was there any joint effusion or tenderness evident?
Patient: No, there was no joint effusion or tenderness evident.
Doctor: And what was the range of your knee motion?
Patient: The range of my knee motion is normal.
Doctor: Hmm. And what did the McMurray and instability tests show?
Patient: The McMurray and instability tests were negative.
Doctor: And what were the laboratory findings?
Patient: The laboratory findings were within normal ranges.
Doctor: I see. And what did the simple radiographs of both knees show?
Patient: The simple radiographs of both knees showed no specific bony abnormality.
Doctor: Hmm. And what did the MRI show this time?
Patient: The MRI showed a 6 mm × 3.5 mm × 3 mm sized intermediate-low signal intensity nodular lesion on the T1-weighted image and a nodular lesion with central intermediate-low signal intensity surrounded by high signal intensity in the anterosuperior subcortical area of the lateral femoral condyle with adjacent bone marrow edema on the T2-weighted image.
Doctor: Okay. And what did the computed tomography of the right knee demonstrate?
Patient: The computed tomography of the right knee demonstrated a 5 mm × 3 mm × 3 mm sized lesion with the central nidus and perinidal sclerosis in the anterolateral subcortical area of the distal femur.
Doctor: Hmm. And what did the bone scan show?
Patient: The bone scan showed increased uptake at the site corresponding to the lesion in the distal femur.
Doctor: Based on all these findings, we have diagnosed you with osteoid osteoma of the distal femur. We will schedule an arthroscopically assisted excision for you.
Patient: Okay, thank you, doctor.
ideal_response:
A 20-year-old female presented at our outpatient department with a complaint of pain persisting for 12 months in the right knee. The pain that was mild at the time of symptom onset became slightly worse at night without association with knee effusion or swelling. She had no definite history of trauma and denied any medical history of rheumatoid arthritis or any other arthritic diseases. A year before this presentation, she visited another hospital for the same symptom where plain radiography and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the knee were performed. The patient knew plain radiographs showed normal findings but MRI revealed a widespread signal change in the subchondral bone of the lateral femoral condyle. The initial diagnosis was bone bruise of the lateral femoral condyle, and she was treated conservatively using intermittent nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug medication and physical therapy, which did not result in pain relief.
When the patient presented at Dongguk University Gyeongju Hospital, she complained of pain in the anterolateral aspect of the right knee, but joint effusion or tenderness was not evident and the range of knee motion was normal. McMurray and instability tests were negative, and laboratory findings were within normal ranges. Simple radiographs of both knees showed no specific bony abnormality, but the MRI showed a 6 mm × 3.5 mm × 3 mm sized intermediate-low signal intensity nodular lesion on the T1-weighted image and a nodular lesion with central intermediate-low signal intensity surrounded by high signal intensity in the anterosuperior subcortical area of the lateral femoral condyle with adjacent bone marrow edema on the T2-weightedimage (). Computed tomography (CT) of the right knee demonstrated a 5 mm × 3 mm × 3 mm sized lesion with the central nidus and perinidal sclerosis in the anterolateral subcortical area of the distal femur (). Bone scan showed increased uptake at the site corresponding to the lesion in the distal femur (). A diagnosis of osteoid osteoma of the distal femur was established and an arthroscopically assisted excision was scheduled.

prompt:
You are a helpful assistant that can generate a clinical note from a conversation transcript between a patient and a doctor.

Doctor: Good morning, what brings you here today?
Patient: Hi, I had an injury while playing with my friends a week ago. I have been feeling acute pain in my left knee.
Doctor: I see. Can you tell me more about the injury and the pain you are experiencing?
Patient: Yes, I was playing and suddenly I felt a sharp pain in my left knee. I was transferred to the emergency department from a local hospital.
Doctor: Okay, I understand. Can you tell me more about the physical examination you had at the local hospital?
Patient: Yes, they did a physical examination on my left lower limb and they said there was no evidence of acute ischemia, like paleness, coldness, or weak presence of a dorsalis pedis artery pulse.
Doctor: Okay, that's good. And what did the simple X-ray show?
Patient: It showed only soft tissue swelling, with no evidence of knee dislocation, like posterior subluxation of the proximal tibia.
Doctor: I see. And what about the MRI results?
Patient: The MRI showed bicruciate ligament injury and mild occlusion of the popliteal artery at the knee level.
Doctor: Okay, thank you for sharing that information with me. To evaluate the integrity of the popliteal artery, we immediately performed a CT angiography, which showed complete obstruction of the popliteal artery. But, we were lucky to see that the medial genicular artery was well developed and showed good collateral circulation at the knee joint.
Patient: Hmm, okay.
Doctor: We had to perform an emergency surgical intervention to salvage the ischemic limb. During the surgery, we found a thrombotic occlusion from just distal to superomedial genicular artery branch to just proximal to the trifurcation level. And, the arteriotomy showed a 8 cm long tear of intima.
Patient: Okay.
Doctor: So, we had to excise the damaged artery and do a graft interposition using a reversed saphenous vein graft because thrombectomy and intimal repair were thought of high recurrence of thrombotic occlusion.
Patient: Hmm, okay.
Doctor: And then, to acquire stability of the knee joint, we performed a posterior cruciate ligament reconstruction with an achilles tendon allograft by inlay technique.
Patient: Okay.
Doctor: After the surgery, the dosalis pedis arterial pulses were slightly decreased, but were postoperatively recovered immediately. We started the anticoagulant 12 hours after the surgery and maintained it until 1 year after the surgery. We used heparin for one week after the surgery and warfarin thereafter.
Patient: Hmm, okay.
Doctor: The rehabilitation schedule was delayed one week to confirm the circulation persistence after the anastomosis. And, we carried out a follow up CT angiography one week after the surgery, which showed satisfactory arterial flow without any complications like postoperative stenosis, pseudoaneurysm, or thrombotic occlusion.
Patient: Okay.
Doctor: You can start your active quadriceps knee motion exercises from 90° to 0° one week after the surgery. And, you can start your knee flexion exercises as well.
Patient: Okay, thank you doctor.
Doctor: You're welcome. If you have any questions or concerns, please feel free to ask.

Patient: Yes, there was leakage of the serum physiologic from the orifice on the ventral side of my penis.
Doctor: And what was the result of the fistulography?
Patient: It showed the fistula tract.
Doctor: Okay. So, we performed total excision of the fistula tract under spinal anesthesia with the intention of definitive treatment. And what happened during the procedure?
Patient: The urethral fistula tract was observed and totally excised. No graft was used during the primary closure after excision of the tract.
Doctor: That's good. And what was the outcome after the urinary diversion was performed using a long-term silastic catheter introduced per urethra?
Patient: There was no urine leakage observed and the catheter was removed on the third week. The wound healed very well.
Doctor: Excellent. And have you had any recurrence of cellulitis or fistula since then?
Patient: No, I have remained well with no recurrence of cellulitis or fistula 24 months postoperatively.
Doctor: That's great to hear. You are doing well now. Is there anything else you would like to ask me?
Patient: No, I think you have explained everything clearly. Thank you, doctor.
Doctor: You're welcome. If you have any questions or concerns in the future, don't hesitate to come back and see me.
ideal_response:
A 69-year-old Turkish Caucasian man was admitted to our urology clinic with recurrence urinary tract infection and chronic intermittent discharge from the ventral side of the penis. He reported that one week before his admission to our clinic he had experienced urinary retention, and was urethral catheterized in another medical center. However, after four days of the urethral catheterization, the patient had withdrawn the urethral catheter himself without deflating the balloon. His medical history included controlled hypertension disease but not diabetes mellitus. Two years before his last presentation to the clinic, he was diagnosed with bladder stone disease, and was treated with diverticulectomy and cystolithotomy. His systemic examination was not significant for any specific disorder. Local examination revealed an orifice of a possible fistula on the ventral side of the penis. His serum glucose level was 93.8 mg/dl, white blood cell count 10.7 × 109/L. Increased leukocyte count and bacteria were observed in the urine analysis. He was admitted to hospital with a possible diagnosis of urethral fistula. In his initial management broad spectrum antibiotics were used to control the urinary sepsis. Bacteriology confirmed a heavy growth of gram negative basil.
During cystoscopy leakage of the serum physiologic from the orifice on the ventral side of the penis was observed, and no other pathology was noted. A fistulography was performed in order to demonstrate the fistula tract (Figure ). Total excision of the fistula tract under spinal anesthesia was performed with the intention of definitive treatment of the patient. During the procedure the urethral fistula tract was observed and totally excised (Figure ). No graft was used during the primary closure after excision of the tract. Urinary diversion was performed with a long-term silastic catheter introduced per urethra. Postoperatively, urine leakage was not observed and the catheter was removed on the third week. Excellent wound healing was seen in figure . The patient was able to void without any problems. He remained well with no recurrence of cellulitis or fistula 24 months postoperatively.

prompt:
You are a helpful assistant that can generate a clinical note from a conversation transcript between a patient and a doctor.

Doctor: Good morning, how are you feeling today?
Patient: I'm okay, thanks.
Doctor: I understand that you were referred to us for drug resistant atrial tachycardia. Can you tell me more about your symptoms?
Patient: Yes, I've been experiencing tachycardia during exercise for the past 4 to 5 years. It makes me feel dizzy and my heart rate goes up to 250 bpm.
Doctor: Hmm, I see. Have you also experienced any slower ectopic rhythms?
Patient: Yes, I have. They were recorded around 100 bpm.
Doctor: Okay, and have you noticed any blocks in your heart during the tachycardia?
Patient: Yes, I have. Various degrees of atrioventricular block have been seen.
Doctor: I see. You were initially treated with flecainide 100 mg bid, correct?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: And have you noticed any changes in your tachycardia since then?
Patient: Yes, it recurred many times a week for the past 3 to 4 months. It lasts from 1 minute to a couple of hours.
Doctor: I see. Is there any past medical history that you would like to share with me?
Patient: No, there isn't.
Doctor: Alright. I would like to perform a physical examination on you. Is that okay?
Patient: Yes, of course.
Doctor: Alright, let's proceed. (after the examination) Everything looks normal. I would also like to perform an echocardiogram on you.
Patient: Okay.
Doctor: (after the echocardiogram) The echocardiogram results are normal, too. I would like to perform an electrophysiological study on you.
Patient: Okay.
Doctor: (after the electrophysiological study) The results show that initially, only supraventricular premature beats were seen. Compared with sinus rhythm, there was a slight reduction in the amplitude of the positive P in Lead 1, the P waves were more positive in Lead 2, Lead 3, AVF, the P waves were inverted in AVL compared with sinus rhythm and there was a change in polarity of the P wave in V1 from biphasic positive negative to positive.
Patient: Hmm.
Doctor: A non-sustained atrial tachycardia at 220 bpm with 2/1 block occurred after atrial burst pacing and showed P waves of the same polarity as the premature beats.
Patient: Okay.
Doctor: At times, a slow regular atrial rhythm around 45 bpm was seen with alternating sinus and ectopic rhythm.
Patient: Hmm.
Doctor: Intracardiac measurements showed that during the premature beats and the tachycardia the high right atrium and the coronary sinus os were activated simultaneously and that the lateral wall of the right atrium was late.
Patient: Okay.
Doctor: The differential diagnosis based on right atrial mapping is a focus in the right interatrial septum, a focus in the non-coronary aortic cusp, a focus in the left interatrial septum, and a focus in the right upper pulmonary vein. The earliest atrial activation during the arrhythmia was found in the high right septal area with a prematurity of minus 30 ms in relation with the beginning of the P wave. Pacing at that site was the best.
Patient: Hmm.
Doctor: Based on the results, I suggest that we proceed with pacing at the high right septal area. I will also prescribe some medications for you to take. Please follow up with me in a week.
Patient: Okay, thank you doctor.

prompt:
You are a helpful assistant that can generate a clinical note from a conversation transcript between a patient and a doctor.

Doctor: Good morning, What brings you here today?
Patient: I have been having pain in my left shoulder and arm.
Doctor: Can you describe the pain?
Patient: It's like a continuous stabbing and electrical shock.
Doctor: I see. And how long have you been experiencing this pain?
Patient: It started about a month ago after an operation.
Doctor: What kind of operation did you have?
Patient: I had an excision and biopsy of chondroblastoma in my left humeral head.
Doctor: Hmm, I see. And do you have any decreased power in your hand grip?
Patient: Yeah, I do.
Doctor: Did you have any nerve damage on electromyelography?
Patient: No, I didn't.
Doctor: On a scale of 0 to 100, how would you rate your pain using the visual analogue scale?
Patient: It's 70.
Doctor: Okay. And did you experience any hyperalgesia, allodynia, muscular atrophy or tremor in your left forearm?
Patient: Yes, I did.
Doctor: I see. And the results of your 3 phase bone scan showed an increase of vascular flow on your left humeral head, and an infra red image of your upper limbs showed that the temperature of your left forearm was lower than your right by 1.72 degrees. Based on your symptoms, physical examinations, and the infra red images, we have diagnosed you with CRPS type 1.
Patient: Hmm.
Doctor: We started you on oral medication and tried continuous cervical epidural catheterization, thoracic sympathetic ganglion block, cervical nerve root block, brachial plexus block, and intravenous injection of local anesthetics and ketamin. And your symptoms were controlled to around 40/100 on the visual analogue scale.
Patient: Yeah, that's right.
Doctor: But after your summer vacation, while you were attending school regularly, you complained about having severe pain several times a day because of making contact with friends. And you were rushed to the emergency room more often than before, and the treatments that we had used before with success didn't work anymore.
Patient: Yeah, that's correct.
Doctor: And now, your pain is 80/100 on the visual analogue scale and getting more severe. And it's broadening to the tips of your left hand fingers, especially you feel a cutting-like pain on your left fifth finger, allodynia even with breeze and squeezing pain, and a limited range of motion with tremor.
Patient: Yeah, that's right.
Doctor: We initially considered spinal cord stimulator insertion, but we were afraid of stimulation electrode migration because you are still growing 8 centimeters per year.
Patient: Hmm.
Doctor: Therefore, we decided to try TSB and explained about the validity of using this procedure for uncontrollable pain. We also explained the side effects.
Patient: Okay.
Doctor: Do you have any questions or concerns about TSB?
Patient: No, I don't.
Doctor: Alright, we will schedule the procedure for you soon. In the meantime, if you have any questions or concerns, please don't hesitate to let us know.
Patient: Okay, thank you.
Doctor: You're welcome.

The delayed phase of a 3 phase bone scan showed an increase of vascular flow on the left humeral head and an infra red image of upper limbs revealed the temperature of the left forearm was lower than the right one by 1.72 degree (). By his symptoms, physical examinations, and the infra red images, we diagnosed the patient as having CRPS type 1 and started oral medication and tried continuous cervical epidural catheterization, thoracic sympathetic ganglion block, cervical nerve root block, brachial plexus block and intravenous injection of local anesthetics and ketamin, so his symptoms were controlled around 40/100 on VAS. However, after summer vacation, while attending school regularly, the patient complained about having severe pain several times a day because of making contact with friends and he was rushed to the emergency room more often than before, and did not respond to any of treatments that we had used before with success. VAS was 80/100 and getting more severe and broadening to the tips of the left hand fingers; especially, he felt a cutting-like pain on the left fifth finger, allodynia even with breeze and squeezing pain, and a limited range of motion with tremor. prompt:
You are a helpful assistant that can generate a clinical note from a conversation transcript between a patient and a doctor. 

The conversation transcript is given below: 

Doctor: Good morning, how are you feeling today?
Patient: I'm feeling okay, doctor.
Doctor: I understand that you were admitted to our hospital because of a recurrence of left pneumothorax. Can you tell me more about your previous history?
Patient: Yes, I had left and right pneumothorax when I was 15 and 16 years old, respectively. They were treated by VATS.
Doctor: I see. And what kind of operation was carried out during the previous VATS procedure?
Patient: A simple resection of apical bullous lesion was carried out without surgical pleurodesis or covering any prosthetic sheets such as polyglycolic acid (PGA) sheets.
Doctor: Alright. I understand that after the chest drainage, the left lung inflated quite well and air leakage disappeared immediately. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: And I understand that VATS was planned for the surgical indication of the second postoperative recurrence. Can you tell me more about that?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: I see. Before the operation, a preoperative non-enhanced computed tomography (CT) scan of the chest was done, and it showed that the abnormally dilated pulmonary artery and pulmonary vein in the lingular segment ran towards the chest wall scar remaining at the surgical port site used at the previous operation. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: Okay. During the operation, a small bullous lesion arising in segment 6 of the left lung was ligated, and the dilated pulsating pulmonary vessels at the periphery of the lingular segment adhered to the chest wall scar remaining at the thoracoscopy port site that was previously made in the fourth intercostal space. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: I see. After the operation, a contrast-enhanced CT scan was done for a suspected diagnosis of pulmonary vessel malformation. Can you tell me what the examination revealed?
Patient: Yes, the examination revealed an abnormal connection between the branch of the systemic artery of the chest wall and the dilated pulmonary artery and pulmonary vein in the lingular segment.
Doctor: I see. And I understand that left subclavian selective arteriography also showed hypertrophic blood vessels that arose from the internal thoracic artery, the lateral thoracic artery, and the subscapular artery arising from the axillary artery, which drained into the both the pulmonary artery and the pulmonary vein in the lingular segment. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: Alright. Based on the chest CT scan obtained at the first episode of left pneumothorax, it showed no parietopulmonary fistula. So, a secondary SAPVF caused by the first VATS for the pneumothorax was diagnosed. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: I see. And I understand that you had no symptoms after the cure of pneumothorax, but the vascular abnormalities might lead to shunt-induced pulmonary hypertension, heart failure, hemoptysis, and possibly rupture. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: Alright. I'll keep an eye on your condition and we'll monitor you closely. It's important to be aware of any symptoms that might arise. If you experience any symptoms, please do not hesitate to come back to see me.
Patient: Okay, doctor. Thank you.
ideal_response:
A 19-year-old man was admitted to our hospital because of recurrence of left pneumothorax. His previous history included left and right pneumothorax at the ages of 15 and 16 years, respectively, which were treated by VATS. In the previous operation, simple resection of apical bullous lesion was carried out without surgical pleurodesis or covering any prosthetic sheets such as polyglycolic acid (PGA) sheets. Although the left lung inflated quite well and air leakage disappeared immediately after chest drainage, VATS was planned for the surgical indication of second postoperative recurrence. A preoperative non-enhanced computed tomography (CT) scan of the chest showed that the abnormally dilated pulmonary artery and pulmonary vein in the lingular segment ran towards the chest wall scar remaining at the surgical port site used at the previous operation (Fig. ). In this operation, a small bullous lesion arising in segment 6 of the left lung was ligated, and the dilated pulsating pulmonary vessels at the periphery of the lingular segment adhered to the aforementioned chest wall scar remaining at the thoracoscopy port site that was previously made in the fourth intercostal space (Fig. ). After this operation, we used contrast-enhanced CT scan for a suspected diagnosis of pulmonary vessel malformation. The examination revealed an abnormal connection between the branch of the systemic artery of the chest wall and the dilated pulmonary artery and pulmonary vein in the lingular segment. Left subclavian selective arteriography also showed hypertrophic blood vessels that arose from the internal thoracic artery, the lateral thoracic artery, and the subscapular artery arising from the axillary artery, which drained into the both the pulmonary artery and the pulmonary vein in the lingular segment (Fig. ). Because the chest CT scan obtained at the first episode of left pneumothorax showed no parietopulmonary fistula, a secondary SAPVF caused by first VATS for the pneumothorax was diagnosed.
The patient had no symptoms after the cure of pneumothorax, but the vascular abnormalities might lead to shunt-induced pulmonary hypertension, heart failure, hemoptysis, and possibly rupture.

Doctor: And there was no history of abdominal trauma in the past. Is that correct?

Patient: That's great. Thank you for everything.

Doctor: Hi, how are you feeling today? 
Patient: I'm okay, doctor. 
Doctor: I understand you have been suffering from intractable pain for a long time. Can you tell me more about it? 
Patient: Yes, I was involved in a motor vehicle accident when I was 16 and suffered a right femoral neck fracture. I had a total hip arthroplasty, but it has been revised four times already. 
Doctor: I see. And now you are here for a fifth revision surgery, correct? 
Patient: Yes, I am. 
Doctor: During the revision procedure, there were some complications, right? 
Patient: Yes, there was a femoral shaft fracture and a deep pelvic arterial injury. 
Doctor: I see. And that resulted in intra-operative hemodynamic instability, correct? 
Patient: Yes, it did. 
Doctor: After that, you were transferred to the intensive care unit and then returned to the OR for completion of the original procedure, is that correct? 
Patient: Yes, that's correct. 
Doctor: And then, you developed increased pain, redness, and new drainage from your surgical wound. 
Patient: Yes, I did. 
Doctor: And then, you underwent surgical exploration and were found to have a hematoma with evidence of defects in the deep fascia, correct? 
Patient: Yes, that's right. 
Doctor: And then, you were started on vancomycin, is that correct? 
Patient: Yes, I was. 
Doctor: And then, you were switched to imipenem 500 mg IV every 6 hours on day 15 in hospital, correct? 
Patient: Yes, that's correct. 
Doctor: And you were not considered to be a candidate for removal of your prosthesis because of the recent prior surgical complications, correct? 
Patient: Yes, that's correct. 
Doctor: And then, you returned to the OR for debridement because of continued fevers despite imipenem, is that right? 
Patient: Yes, I did. 
Doctor: And then, you improved and were discharged home on day 53 to complete your imipenem therapy at home, correct? 
Patient: Yes, that's right. 
Doctor: And now, you are seen weekly in our Orthopedic Infectious, correct? 
Patient: Yes, I am. 
Doctor: Alright, I will make a plan for you. You need to continue taking imipenem and come to see me weekly. 
Patient: Alright, doctor.
ideal_response:
A 47-year-old woman was involved in a motor vehicle accident at the age of 16 and suffered a right femoral neck fracture. Open reduction internal fixation of the fracture was not possible, and the primary therapy for the injury was a total hip arthroplasty (THA). The patient required four revisions of her primary total hip. She presented to our center for consideration for a fifth revision surgery secondary to intractable pain. She was taken to the operating room (OR) and received peri-operative cefazolin as per protocol. Complications arose during the revision procedure. A femoral shaft fracture occurred, and a deep pelvic arterial injury resulted in intra-operative hemodynamic instability, requiring suspension of the procedure and arterial embolization. The patient was subsequently transferred to the intensive care unit and, on day 2 in hospital, returned to the OR for completion of the original procedure which was uneventful. Her postoperative course, however, was complicated by prolonged respiratory failure necessitating a tracheostomy.
On day 12 in hospital, the patient developed increased pain, redness and new drainage from her surgical wound. She underwent surgical exploration, was found to have a hematoma with evidence of defects in the deep fascia, which required debridement down to the hip prosthesis. The hematoma was evacuated, no antibiotic beads were placed, and she was started on vancomycin. Quantitative cultures were not performed; however, tissue cultures grew ampicillin-sensitive Enterococcus species and A. baumannii (sensitive only to amikacin and imipenem). The patient was switched to imipenem 500 mg IV every 6 hours on day 15 in hospital. She was not considered to be a candidate for removal of her prosthesis because of the recent prior surgical complications.
On day 33 in hospital, the patient returned to the OR for debridement because of continued fevers despite imipenem; cultures once again grew MDR A. baumannii, Enterococcus species and coagulase-negative Staphylococci (CNS). The patient improved and was discharged home on day 53 to complete her imipenem therapy at home.
The patient was seen weekly in our Orthopedic Infectious

prompt:
You are a helpful assistant that can generate a clinical note from a conversation transcript between a patient and a doctor. 

The conversation transcript is given below: 

Doctor: Good morning, what brings you here today?
Patient: Good morning doctor, I have been experiencing severe pain in my head for the past few days.
Doctor: Can you tell me a little bit more about your symptoms?
Patient: Sure, I have been experiencing rotational vertigo and vomiting.
Doctor: Hmm, I see. Do you have a history of depression and floating dizziness?
Patient: Yes, I have had a history of depression and floating dizziness, but my symptoms had subsided in recent years and were not a hindrance to my daily life.
Doctor: Okay, and is there any family history of inheritance vascular wall disease?
Patient: No, there is no family history of inheritance vascular wall disease.
Doctor: Alright, thank you for the information. Can you tell me more about when your symptoms first started?
Patient: Sure, on the morning of the day of symptom onset, I developed rotational vertigo of no apparent cause. In the afternoon, I developed pain in the left occipital to temporal regions of the head while driving and subsequently started vomiting in the night.
Doctor: I see. And what did you do next?
Patient: I visited my local neurology clinic on the second day of symptom onset and underwent a computed tomography (CT) scan of the head and plain radiography of the neck.
Doctor: Did the CT scan and radiography show any abnormal findings?
Patient: No, there were no obvious abnormal findings and a diagnosis of suspected herpes zoster was made.
Doctor: I see. What medication were you prescribed with?
Patient: I was prescribed with valaciclovir, pregabalin, and acetaminophen but with no symptom improvement. Carbamazepine and aspirin that were added to the prescription were also ineffective and, hence, I was referred to your anesthesiology pain clinic for examination.
Doctor: Okay, I understand. Can you rate your headache on a visual analog scale (VAS)?
Patient: Yes, my headache is rated 100 mm on a visual analog scale (VAS).
Doctor: Hmm, that's severe. Can you describe the pain in more detail?
Patient: Every few hours, I develop throbbing, pulsatile pain that prevents me from sleeping and renders me practically bedridden during the day. The associated vomiting also prevents me from eating.
Doctor: I see. Are there any other symptoms such as allodynia of the head, trigeminal paresthesia, or motor symptoms in the region of the facial nerve?
Patient: No, there is no allodynia of the head, trigeminal paresthesia, or motor symptoms in the region of the facial nerve.
Doctor: Alright, thank you. Are there any other abnormal neurological findings in the spinal nerve region or skin rash over the left occipital to temporal regions of the head?
Patient: No, there are no other abnormal neurological findings in the spinal nerve region and I have no skin rash over the left occipital to temporal regions of the head.
Doctor: Okay, are there any symptoms of bulbar conjunctival congestion, fever, or meningeal irritation?
Patient: No, there are no bulbar conjunctival congestion, fever, or symptoms of meningeal irritation.
Doctor: I see. Can you tell me your blood pressure?
Patient: My blood pressure was elevated to 160/100 mmHg.
Doctor: Alright, I understand. Based on your symptoms, it seems that your symptoms are in line with the diagnostic criteria for migraine without aura according to the International Classification of Headache Disorders.
Patient: Hmm, okay.
Doctor: I would like to prescribe you with some medication to help with your symptoms. I would also like to see you again in a few weeks to monitor your progress.
Patient: Alright, thank you doctor.

prompt:
You are a helpful assistant that can generate a clinical note from a conversation transcript between a patient and a doctor. 

The conversation transcript is given below: 

Doctor: "Hello there, how are you feeling today?"
Patient: "I'm feeling okay, thank you."
Doctor: "So, you presented to the antenatal clinic at 19 weeks and 3 days' gestation to discuss the results of your morphology scan. Is that correct?"
Patient: "Yes, that's right."
Doctor: "The scan demonstrated a grade 4 placenta previa covering the cervical os. Can you tell me more about your medical history? I see you had a craniotomy in 2006 for Arnold Chiari malformation and correction of a Syringomyelia in 2005."
Patient: "Yes, that's correct. I also suffer from irritable bowel syndrome but I'm not taking any regular medications."
Doctor: "I see. And your first pregnancy resulted in a spontaneous miscarriage that did not require dilatation and curettage. Your second pregnancy resulted in a planned elective caesarean due to concerns about raised intracranial pressure during labor."
Patient: "That's right."
Doctor: "During your current pregnancy, the morphology scan demonstrated a small omphalocele but otherwise no significant structural defects and estimated fetal weight was noted to be within the normal range. However, during the clinic review, the fetus was found to have a heart rate well below 100 bpm. Repeat ultrasound the following day confirmed IUFD."
Patient: "Yes, unfortunately that's what happened."
Doctor: "This ultrasound also demonstrated evidence of an abnormally invasive placenta with the appearance of dysplastic vascular hypertrophy. An obstetric MRI was performed which supported the diagnosis of morbidly adherent placenta. This showed a low lying inhomogeneous placenta, dysplastic vascular hypertrophy, ill-defined placental bands, and an overall impression of some areas of increta with no overt evidence of percreta."
Patient: "I see."
Doctor: "We discussed options with you and you decided for conservative management in order to optimize your chance of preserving your fertility. This was balanced against potential complications of prolonged conservative management of an IUFD, including sepsis and coagulopathy. We made a plan for serial ultrasounds as an outpatient, to be followed by induction of labor when placental blood flow was no longer detectable. However, you were admitted to the hospital with abdominal cramping and associated small antepartum hemorrhage 27 days following IUFD confirmation."
Patient: "Yes, that's right."
Doctor: "An ultrasound scan at 31 days showed a minimal reduction in blood flow. We need to closely monitor your condition and consider the best course of action going forward. Do you have any questions for me?"
Patient: "No, not at the moment."
Doctor: "Okay, we'll continue to monitor your condition and keep you informed of any changes. Thank you for coming in today."
(Patient eventually passes away)
Doctor: "I'm sorry to inform you that the patient has passed away. We will be in contact with the family to discuss next steps."
ideal_response:
A 31-year-old gravida 3 para 1 patient presented to antenatal clinic at 19 weeks and 3 days' gestation to discuss the results of her morphology scan which had demonstrated a grade 4 placenta previa covering the cervical os. She had a medical history significant for Arnold Chiari malformation requiring craniotomy in 2006 as well as correction of a Syringomyelia in 2005. She also suffers from irritable bowel syndrome but was taking no regular medications and had a BMI of 23. Her first pregnancy resulted in a spontaneous miscarriage that did not require dilatation and curettage. Her second pregnancy resulted in a planned elective caesarean due to concerns about raised intracranial pressure during labour, as recommended by her neurologist. She had routine antenatal care this pregnancy which had been unremarkable to date.
The morphology scan demonstrated a small omphalocele but otherwise no significant structural defects and estimated foetal weight was noted to be within the normal range. During the clinic review, the fetus was found to have a heart rate well below 100 bpm. Repeat ultrasound the following day confirmed IUFD. This ultrasound also demonstrated evidence of an abnormally invasive placenta with the appearance of dysplastic vascular hypertrophy. An obstetric MRI was performed which supported the diagnosis of morbidly adherent placenta. This showed a low lying inhomogeneous placenta, dysplastic vascular hypertrophy, ill-defined placental bands, and an overall impression of some areas of increta with no overt evidence of percreta.
Options were discussed with the patient who decided for conservative management in order to optimise her chance of preserving her fertility. This was balanced against potential complications of prolonged conservative management of an IUFD, including sepsis and coagulopathy. A plan was made for serial ultrasounds as an outpatient, to be followed by induction of labour when placental blood flow was no longer detectable. Twenty-seven days following IUFD confirmation, the patient was admitted to hospital with abdominal cramping and associated small antepartum haemorrhage (APH).
Ultrasound scan at 31 days showed a minimal reduction in blood flow

Doctor: Good morning, how are you feeling today?
Patient: I'm feeling okay, doctor.
Doctor: Can you tell me what brought you here today?
Patient: Yes, I have stress-related urinary incontinence.
Doctor: I see. Can you tell me a little bit about your medical history?
Patient: I'm a 35-year-old multiparous woman and I have no history of surgery or illness.
Doctor: Okay. And have you noticed any other symptoms besides stress-related urinary incontinence?
Patient: No, just that.
Doctor: Alright. We performed a TVT placement under spinal anesthesia for you. Can you tell me what happened after the procedure?
Patient: After the procedure, I was hospitalized overnight and the catheter was removed the next morning. I voided without residual urine, but one hour later, I developed acute abdominal pain and a fever.
Doctor: I see. We did some tests and examinations. Can you tell me what the results showed?
Patient: The examination of the suprapubic area revealed diffuse abdominal rebound tenderness without any discharge from the operation site. The Vital signs, urinary drainage, and laboratory studies showed normal results.
Doctor: Okay. And what about the computerized tomography of the abdomen and pelvis?
Patient: The computerized tomography showed multiple dilated bowel loops and abnormal fluid collection in the peritoneal space.
Doctor: I see. And what about the cystogram?
Patient: The cystogram demonstrated a leakage of contrast media into the peritoneal cavity.
Doctor: Alright. And what did the cystoscopy show?
Patient: The cystoscopy showed a pinhead-sized ulcerative lesion on the right lateral wall, but with no visible perforation into the peritoneal cavity.
Doctor: I see. We performed an emergency exploratory laparotomy for you. Can you tell me what happened during the laparotomy?
Patient: During the laparotomy, we found general peritonitis and a large intraperitoneal hematoma, with the tape penetrating the pelvic peritoneum without causing bowel injury. The right tape penetrated the bladder muscle and mucosa, close to the site of the right trocar's passage. The hematoma was removed and the bladder and peritoneum were repaired.
Doctor: I see. And how have you been feeling since the laparotomy?
Patient: I've been recovering with antibiotic management and I was discharged one week after the laparotomy.
Doctor: That's great to hear. Do you have any questions or concerns about your condition?
Patient: No, not really.
Doctor: Alright. Well, if you have any questions or concerns in the future, don't hesitate to come back and see me.
Patient: Okay, thank you, doctor.
[Conversation ends]

Doctor: Hello, are you a family member of the patient?
Family member: Yes, I am. How is she doing?
Doctor: She's doing well. She was discharged one week after the laparotomy and she's been recovering with antibiotic management.
Family member: That's great to hear. Thank you, doctor.
Doctor: You're welcome. If you have any questions or concerns, don't hesitate to ask.
Family member: Thank you, doctor.
[Family member leaves the room]
Doctor: (to himself) Another successful case. Time to move on to the next patient. [Conversation ends]

She had normal urethral closure pressure and no bladder instability. The patient was selected for TVT placement under spinal anesthesia. Just after insertion of the TVT trocar, the bladder was examined by cystoscopy and there was no sign of perforation. We did not perform an additional cystoscopy after extraction of the trocar. The remainder of the procedure was uneventful. A 16-Fr urethral Foley catheter was used to drain the bladder, and the patient was hospitalized overnight. The next morning, approximately 24 h after surgery, the catheter was removed and she voided without residual urine. Approximately one hour after removing the catheter, she developed acute abdominal pain and a fever. An examination of the suprapubic area revealed diffuse abdominal rebound tenderness without any discharge from the operation site. Vital signs, urinary drainage and laboratory studies showed normal results. Computerized tomography of the abdomen and pelvis demonstrated multiple dilated bowel loops and abnormal fluid collection in the peritoneal space (). A cystogram demonstrated a leakage of contrast media into the peritoneal cavity (). Cystoscopy also revealed a pinhead-sized ulcerative lesion on the right lateral wall, but with no visible perforation into the peritoneal cavity (). Emergency exploratory laparotomy via a lower midline incision revealed general peritonitis, as well as a large intraperitoneal hematoma, with the tape penetrating the pelvic peritoneum without concomitantly causing bowel injury. The right tape penetrated the deep layers of the bladder muscle and mucosa, close to the site of right trocar's passage. The hematoma around the perforated lesion was removed. The retroperitoneal portion of the right tape, just below the bladder rupture site, was cut as low as possible and the tape above the cut area was removed. We did not remove the periurethral and left portions of the tape. The bladder and peritoneum were repaired. You are a helpful assistant that can generate a clinical note from a conversation transcript between a patient and a doctor.

Patient: No, I am unable to bend it.
Doctor: Hmm, I understand. Were you diagnosed with a ruptured patellar tendon?
Patient: Yes, I was diagnosed at a community hospital and was managed with immobilization using a long leg splint.
Doctor: Alright. And you were referred to our hospital 5 hours after the injury. Can you tell me more about your knee pain?
Patient: Yes, I have persistent anterior knee pain and can't bend my knee. There's also a skin dimple inferior to my patella.
Doctor: Okay. I see. I would like to take a look at your lateral radiograph of the right knee. Can I have a look?

prompt:
You are a helpful assistant that can generate a clinical note from a conversation transcript between a patient and a doctor. 

The conversation transcript is given below: 

Doctor: Hello, how are you feeling today?
Patient: I'm feeling fine, thank you.
Doctor: I see that you were admitted to our hospital by your family doctor after a routine clinical examination. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's right.
Doctor: During that examination, a chest-x-ray showed a mediastinal mass overlapping the aortic arch region. Have you experienced any symptoms related to this?
Patient: No, I haven't experienced any symptoms.
Doctor: Okay. Based on the CT scan that was performed, we can see that there is a type B dissection, which is most likely chronic. This originated from an aneurysm of a left cervical arch with a maximum diameter of 6 cm. Do you understand what that means?
Patient: Not really, could you explain it to me?
Doctor: Essentially, there is a tear in the lining of the aorta that has caused a bulge to form. This bulge could potentially rupture and cause serious internal bleeding, which is why we need to perform a surgical repair as soon as possible.
Patient: I understand.
Doctor: Before the surgery, we will need to adjust your blood pressure with an ACE inhibitor to minimize the risk of complications. We will also be monitoring your neurological function during the procedure using sensitive and motor evoked potentials. Additionally, spinal drainage will be installed 1 day before the procedure.
Patient: Okay.
Doctor: During the surgery, we will be performing a median sternotomy and an additional left lateral thoracic incision through the fourth intercostal space. We will also be using cardiopulmonary bypass, which involves cannulation of the femoral artery and vein under echocardiographic guidance. The left lung will be mobilized by transsection of the Ligamentum pulmonale and preparation of the perianeurysmatic tissue and adhesions.
Patient: That sounds complicated.
Doctor: Yes, it is a complex procedure, but it is necessary to ensure your safety. After identifying and preparing the relevant nerves and branches, we will clamp the descending aorta and perform a distal anastomosis with a straight graft. The visceral arteries will partially branch from the false and true lumen without a sign of malperfusion. Before the final distal anastomosis, we will perform a fenestration of the dissection membrane about a length of 5 cm to keep the perfusion of both lumina. The left carotid artery originates from the aortic arch with a distance of only 1 cm.
Patient: I see. Is there anything else I need to know?
Doctor: After the surgery, we will monitor you closely for any signs of complications. You will need to follow up with your family doctor and attend any recommended appointments to ensure a smooth recovery. If you have any questions or concerns, please don't hesitate to ask. 
Family Member: Excuse me, Doctor. What happened to our family member?
Doctor: I'm sorry to inform you that despite our best efforts, your family member did not survive the surgery. We did everything we could to try and save her, but unfortunately, the risk of rupture was too great. My condolences to you and your family.
ideal_response: A 43-year old, asymptomatic woman was admitted to our hospital by her family doctor after receiving a chest-x-ray during routine clinical examination. The x-ray showed a mediastinal mass overlapping the aortic arch region (Fig. ). For verification a computed tomography (CT) was performed and revealed incidentally a type B dissection, which was most likely chronic without information of the index date, originating from an aneurysm of a left cervical arch with a maximum diameter of 6 cm (Fig. ). The left renal artery, the coeliac trunc and the main part of the superior mesenteric artery branched from the false lumen without a sign of malperfusion of the organs. Because of the huge diameter and the potential risk of rupture, an urgent surgical repair was planned. Before intervention the patient got a blood pressure adjustment by ACE inhibitor. Betablocker was not necessary because of a resting pulse under 60 beats per minute. For neurological online monitoring, sensitive and motor evoked potentials were monitored. Spinal drainage was installed 1 day before the procedure. Surgical access was carried out through median sternotomy and an additional left lateral thoracic incision through the fourth intercostal space (Hemi-Clemshell). Simultaneously to the preparation of the aneurysm, partial cardiopulmonary bypass was installed in the left groin by cannulation of the femoral artery and vein under echocardiographic guidance. During selective ventilation of the right side, the left lung was mobilized by transsection of the Ligamentum pulmonale and preparation of the perianeurysmatic tissue and adhesions. After identification and preparation of the recurrent and phrenic nerve and the supraaortal branches, the descending aorta was clamped and a distal anastomosis performed with a straight graft (20 mm). The visceral arteries partially branched from the false and true lumen without a sign of malperfusion. Before the final distal anastomosis, we performed a fenestration of the dissection membrane about a length of 5 cm to keep the perfusion of both lumina. The left carotid artery originated from the aortic arch with a distance of only 1 cm

Doctor: Good morning, how are you feeling today?
Patient: I'm not feeling well, doctor. I have severe chest pain and shortness of breath.
Doctor: Okay, let me check your medical history. Have you had any hospitalizations in the past for these symptoms?
Patient: No, this is the first time.
Doctor: I see. And where did you go for your first aim treatment?
Patient: I went to a primary healthcare center at a peripheral hospital.
Doctor: Alright. Based on your clinical manifestations, we treated you for pulmonary embolic disease with anticoagulant therapy. Later, we had to perform an emergency caesarean delivery to ensure the safety of your baby. How is your baby doing now?
Patient: My baby's Apgar index was 3, 6, and 9 at minutes 1, 3, and 5 respectively. The weight was lower than expected.
Doctor: Yes, the baby's weight was restricted due to the unknown pAVM. Ultrasounds during pregnancy showed a reduction in potential fetal growth from week 33 without any Doppler alteration.
Patient: I see.
Doctor: Also, during the caesarean section, we used general anesthesia because of your condition of increasing dyspnoea. Spinal anesthesia was not indicated due to the risk of association with other AVMs, especially in case of HHT.
Patient: Oh, I didn't know that.
Doctor: Yes, it's important to consider all the risks involved. After the caesarean section, we observed less than 10% infarcts on the placenta. However, your postoperative course showed a worsening of your clinical condition, leading to acute distress syndrome. We had to transfer you to the Gynaecology and Obstetrics unit for critical care.
Patient: That sounds serious.
Doctor: Yes, it was a critical situation, but we did everything we could to ensure your safety and your baby's safety. Do you have any questions for me?
Patient: No, I think you've explained everything very clearly, thank you.
Doctor: You're welcome. Please make sure to follow up with your appointments and take care of yourself. If you have any concerns, don't hesitate to contact us. We'll be here to support you.
ideal_response:
Our patient was a 32-year-old previously healthy female at the 39th week of gestation who accessed the first aim department of a primary healthcare centre of a peripheral hospital for severe dyspnoea and chest pain. Her past medical history did not present other hospitalizations for the same symptoms. Due to the clinical manifestations, the patient was initially treated as a case of pulmonary embolic disease and subjected to a massive anticoagulant therapy. Considering the clinical diagnosis and the child to term, an emergent caesarean delivery was performed in order to avoid foetal complications. The caesarean section was successfully performed under general anaesthesia using Stark's method due to the urgency related to the patient's clinical condition of increasing dyspnoea. Moreover, although the pAVM was still unknown at time of the caesarean section, the execution of spinal anaesthesia seems to be not indicated because of the risk of pAVM association with other AVMs, such as those located in the spinal cord, especially in case of HHT.
The foetal outcome showed an Apgar index of 3, 6, and 9, respectively, at minutes 1, 3, and 5; these data are in line with the administration of general anaesthesia and the acute maternal condition of severe dyspnoea.
Taking into account the foetal weight at birth, it showed a restriction of the expected value. The child weight was in fact 2590 gr at 39 weeks of gestation. However, ultrasounds performed during the pregnancy reported a reduction of the potential foetal growth from the 33 weeks of gestation without any Doppler alteration. This phenomenon should be the result of the chronical adaptation of the pregnancy to the unknown pAVM.
As far as the macroscopic exam of the placenta is concerned, a percentage of cotyledons infarcts inferior than 10% was reported.
Considering the patient's postoperative course, it showed a subsequently worsening of the clinical conditions, resulting in an acute distress syndrome that required an immediate transfer to the Gynaecology and Obstetrics unit of our structure. Due to the critical care panel

Patient: Yes, I have cervical pain that spreads to my shoulders.
Doctor: I see. And I know that electromyography and nerve conduction studies confirmed that you have Guillain Barré Syndrome.
Patient: Yes, that's right.
Doctor: We also performed a complementary MRI as part of the management and found a cystic lesion in the vertebral body of C2.
Patient: Hmm, okay.

Patient: Hmm, okay.

Patient: Hmm, okay.
Doctor: To ensure the stability of the defect, we filled it with cortical/cancellous allograft and prescribed a postsurgical plastic cervical collar to maintain neck immobilization.
Patient: I see.
Doctor: The postoperative evolution was satisfactory. You remained with a CTLSO immobilization for 4 months. And at 6 and 12 months, you presented no symptoms and the postoperative CT scan showed adequate integration of the graft.
Patient: That's great to hear.
Doctor: Yes, it is. And we'll continue to monitor your progress and make any necessary adjustments to your treatment plan.
Patient: Thank you, doctor.

A complementary MRI performed as part of in-hospital management showed an incidental finding of a cystic lesion in the vertebral body of C2 (). The only symptom reported by the patient was cervical pain irradiated to shoulders. The physical exam was unremarkable, and no deformities nor neurologic alterations were noted. The patient started using a Philadelphia collar and restriction of exercise was recommended.
The case was discussed at the neurosurgery, spine surgery, and neuroradiology service meeting and extension studies such as angiotomography of carotid arteries and vertebrobasilar system and bone scintigraphy were requested to determine the etiology of the lesion because the management and prognosis vary according to the type of tumor. Studies concluded it was a tumoral lesion with benign characteristics. Additionally, correlation with computed tomography (CT scan) revealed a focal hypodense lesion in the right half of the vertebral body of C2 with disruption of the inferior cortical. Because of the elevated risk of fracture and collapse of the vertebra due to the thinning of the cortical the optimal treatment considered was surgical resection of the tumor to prevent further neurological lesions. Cervical curettage followed by tumor excision was performed. A lateral submandibular approach to the upper cervical spine was used and bone resection was performed with a radiofrequency assisted burr, no instrumentation or fixation was required. Intraoperatively a cystic lesion with fibrotic and nodular material was evidenced; later histologic examination ruled out giant cell tumor and aneurismatic bone cyst (). The stability of the defect was ensured by filling it with cortical/cancellous allograft and by prescribing a postsurgical plastic cervical collar to maintain neck immobilization.

Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today?
Patient: I presented to the gastroenterology office for a follow-up of a previously found duodenal lesion.
Doctor: Okay, can you tell me more about your medical history and symptoms?
Patient: I had an EGD at an outside facility 2 years earlier for evaluation of abdominal pain which showed a 1.2 cm duodenal polypoid lesion in the second portion of the duodenum.
Doctor: And what did the pathology report reveal?
Patient: The polyp revealed heterotopic gastric mucosa with benign lobules of gastric glands. I also had chronically active H. pylori gastritis with numerous Helicobacter organisms and atrophic gastritis with patchy areas of intestinal metaplasia.
Doctor: Based on your history, we performed an upper endoscopy that showed atrophic gastritis, duodenitis, and a single 10 mm polyp in the second portion of the duodenum. The duodenal polyp was biopsied. What were the results of the biopsy?
Patient: Pathology revealed polypoid gastric metaplastic mucosa with focal epithelial atypia including nuclear enlargement, stratification, nucleoli, and few mitoses.
Doctor: I see. We referred you for endoscopic ultrasound to further characterize the lesion and complete resection. Did you undergo the procedure?
Patient: Yes, several weeks later I underwent an endoscopic ultrasound that revealed a 13-mm pedunculated and sessile polyp on the lateral wall opposite to the major papilla in the second portion of the duodenum.
Doctor: And what was the treatment?
Patient: The polyp was removed en bloc using a hot snare following a 4-mL saline lift. Two endoclips were placed for hemostasis.
Doctor: Okay, and what did the pathology report reveal about the polyp?
Patient: Pathology revealed a pyloric gland adenoma with predominantly low grade dysplasia and some small areas of focal high grade dysplasia.
Doctor: I see. You were recommended to follow up for surveillance upper endoscopy in 6 months due to the areas of high grade dysplasia found on pathology. Did you follow up?
Patient: No, I was lost to follow-up for over one year.
Doctor: Unfortunately, the patient eventually died.
Family: We are very sorry to hear that. Thank you for all your help and care.

Patient: Okay, thank you.

Doctor: I see. Now, I understand that you developed a cardiogenic cerebral infarction 5 years ago. Can you tell me more about that?

Doctor: I see. And prior to that, I understand that you suffered a gunshot wound to your right thigh and had to have your superficial femoral artery ligated 40 years ago. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's right.
Doctor: And I also see that you were thrown from a bridge of approximately 40 meters in height. Can you tell me more about that?
Patient: Yes, I fell off a bridge and hurt my waist and back. But I recovered after being treated.
Doctor: I see. So, what is the relationship between these traumatic events and your current hip pain?
Patient: I don't know.
Doctor: I see. And I understand that you have been aware of a pulsatile mass in your right groin for at least 20 years. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's right.
Doctor: I see. And a contrast-enhanced abdominal computed tomography revealed the presence of an irregular aneurysm from the right common iliac artery to the right common femoral artery, with a maximum diameter of 50mm. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's what the test showed.
Doctor: I see. And I understand that you don't have a history of connective tissue disorders or vasculitis, and a blood analysis revealed no inflammatory findings. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's right.
Doctor: Based on these findings, we have clinically diagnosed you with a right iliac arterial pseudoaneurysm, which we think was caused by an old infection or past trauma. Is that okay with you?
Patient: Yes, that's okay.
Doctor: Great. We have performed surgery to resect the aneurysm and performed in situ reconstruction with a bifurcated vascular prosthesis. And since the right common femoral artery was enlarged and showed severe adhesion to the surrounding tissues due to previous surgery for the gunshot wound, we decided to use the right deep femoral artery for peripheral anastomosis. Do you understand what I just told you?
Patient: Hmm, yes. I think so.
Doctor: Great. And when we entered the abdominal cavity, we found that the right iliac arterial aneurysm was irregular, with a whitish surface, and it adhered to the small intestines. These findings were suggestive of chronic inflammation. And according to the usual procedure, the prosthetic bifurcated graft was anastomosed to the transected aorta, distal of the inferior mesenteric artery, and the left limb of the graft was anastomosed to the left common iliac artery. Do you understand what I just told you?

Although the details were unclear, the patient had suffered a gunshot wound to the right thigh and the superficial femoral artery had been ligated to achieve hemostasis 40 years previously. He had also been thrown from a bridge of approximately 40 m in height. At that time, he injured his waist and back, however, he successfully recovered while being conservatively treated. The relationship between these traumatic events and the current event was unknown; however, he had been aware of a pulsatile mass in his right groin for at least 20 years. Subsequent contrast-enhanced abdominal computed tomography revealed the presence of an irregular aneurysm from the right common iliac artery to the right common femoral artery, the maximum diameter of which was 50 mm (Fig. , ). Since the patient had no history of connective tissue disorders or vasculitis, and a blood analysis revealed no inflammatory findings, we clinically diagnosed the patient with a right iliac arterial pseudoaneurysm, which was thought to have been caused by an old infection or past trauma. We performed surgery to resect the aneurysm and performed in situ reconstruction with a bifurcated vascular prosthesis (Hemashield 16 × 8 mm; MAQUET Holding B.V. & Co. KG, Rastatt, Germany). Since the right common femoral artery was enlarged and showed severe adhesion to the surrounding tissues due to previous surgery for the gunshot wound, we decided to use the right deep femoral artery for peripheral anastomosis. On entering the abdominal cavity, the right iliac arterial aneurysm was irregular, with a whitish surface, and it adhered to the small intestines. These findings were suggestive of chronic inflammation. According to the usual procedure, the prosthetic bifurcated graft was anastomosed to the transected aorta, distal of the inferior mesenteric artery, and the left limb of the graft was anastomosed to the left common iliac artery. prompt:

Doctor: Hi there, what brings you in today?
Patient: I have a complaint about some masses on my baby's body that haven't gone away.
Doctor: Okay, can you tell me more about that? When did you first notice them?
Patient: They've been there since birth, and they haven't changed in size.
Doctor: And how was your pregnancy? Did you have any complications?
Patient: No, it was uneventful. The baby was delivered vaginally at 37 weeks of gestation.
Doctor: I see. Let's do a physical exam and see what we find.
Patient: Okay.
Doctor: So, on the exam, I don't see any jaundice or pallor, and your baby's vitals are all within the normal range.
Patient: That's good to hear.
Doctor: I do notice some masses on the forehead, scalp, and abdomen, but they don't appear to be hemorrhagic.
Patient: Yes, those are the ones we're worried about.
Doctor: I'll order an ultrasound and a Doppler examination to get a better look. In the meantime, I'll also run a full blood count to check for any abnormalities.
Patient: Okay, thank you.
Doctor: The ultrasound and Doppler showed a fast-flow vascular lesion, which is consistent with a diagnosis of congenital hemangioma.
Patient: And what does that mean?
Doctor: It's a benign tumor made up of blood vessels. We'll need to monitor the size of the masses and watch for any complications. But for now, we'll take a wait-and-watch approach and schedule regular visits at three months.
Patient: Sounds good.
Doctor: If the masses fail to regress or continue to grow, we'll discuss surgical treatment options.
Patient: Thank you for explaining everything to us.
ideal_response:
A two-week-old female was brought in with an initial complaint of multiple masses that failed to regress since birth. She was born from a nonconsanguineous union and the mother’s pregnancy was uneventful. The baby was delivered vaginally at 37 weeks of gestation and multiples masses were found over the body. The treating physician advised follow-ups on discharge. However, the parents decided to seek more medical help for the child and she was admitted for more investigations.
On physical exam, the child was alert and active. She was not jaundiced and no pallor was noted on the extremities. Her vitals were all within the normal range and the birth weight and changes in weight corresponded properly. Two masses measuring 26 mm by 19 mm and 19 mm by 17 mm were observed on the forehead and the scalp (Figures -). One smaller mass was seen on the abdomen, measuring 11 mm by 10 mm (Figure ). All three masses were red and non-hemorrhagic. The parents reported that the size of the masses did not change since birth. No similar family history was found and both parents were healthy. Any hepatosplenomegaly was not observed on palpation nor were any other cutaneous lesions detected. She did not present with any other systemic abnormalities. An ultrasound was performed, and it revealed a normal liver, spleen, and kidneys with no masses or lesions. A Doppler examination also showed a fast-flow vascular lesion, as reported by many other articles []. The full blood count showed normal levels of white blood cells, platelets, hematocrit, and red blood cells.
The diagnosis of congenital hemangioma was confirmed and the family was properly educated about the condition as well as possible complications. A wait and watch approach was adopted and the child was scheduled for regular visits at three months. The family was asked to properly monitor the size of the masses and informed that appropriate surgical treatment would be provided if the masses fail to regress or if they continue to grow

prompt:

Doctor: Good morning, I'm Doctor Smith. How can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, I have a report about my medical condition that I need to discuss with you.
Doctor: Sure, I'd be happy to help. Can you tell me what the report says?
Patient: It says I have a mesenteric cyst in my sigmoid colon and the histopathology reported it as a cystadenoma.
Doctor: Hmm, okay. And what symptoms have you been experiencing?
Patient: I've been having left iliac fossa pain and swelling for the past ten months.
Doctor: I see. And have you had any scans or tests done?
Patient: Yes, I had an ultrasound scan of my pelvis and it found a cystic lesion probably from my left ovary.
Doctor: Okay, I understand. And did you have any other tests done?
Patient: Yes, I had some other tests, but they were all normal.
Doctor: Alright. And what was the outcome of the ultrasound scan?
Patient: I was listed for a laparoscopic assisted vaginal hysterectomy, bilateral salpingo-oopherectomy and peritoneal washing.
Doctor: I see. And what happened during the operation?
Patient: The Gynaecologist found a large cyst attached to the mesentery of my sigmoid colon and it was free from my ovaries. The operation was suspended and the on-call general surgical team was called in.
Doctor: Okay, I understand. And what did the general surgical team do?
Patient: They performed a diagnostic laparoscopy and found that all other organs were normal, but it was difficult to assess the anatomy of the cyst and which other organs were involved. They concluded that it was not an ovarian cyst and proceeding with the operation would be risky.

Doctor: I see. And what was the outcome of the follow-up appointment?
Patient: Due to the persisting discomfort, I was booked for an elective laparoscopic removal of the cyst with the possibility of converting it to an open procedure due to the size of the mass.
Doctor: I understand. And what was the outcome of the removal procedure?

During the operation the Gynaecologist found a large 10 × 15 cm2 cyst attached to the mesentery of the sigmoid colon free from the ovaries. Doctor: Good morning, how are you feeling today?
Patient: I'm not feeling very good, doctor.
Doctor: I see. You were admitted to the inpatient ward with a complaint of suicidal ideation. Can you tell me more about that?
Patient: Yes, I have been struggling with suicidal thoughts for a while now.
Doctor: I see. You have a past history of multiple psychiatric disorders, including BPD, MDD, and anxiety issues. Can you tell me more about those?
Patient: Yes, I have been dealing with those for about eight to 10 years now.
Doctor: I see. It says in your clinical note that you have had multiple suicide attempts in the past. Can you tell me more about those?
Patient: Yes, the most recent one was two weeks ago when I tried to suffocate myself with the help of a medical device tubing.
Doctor: I see. On inquiry, you said you just wanted to feel the pain, not kill yourself. Can you tell me more about that?
Patient: Yes, I just wanted to feel something, anything. I feel so numb all the time.
Doctor: I see. On further questioning, you were found to have passive suicidal thoughts as well as an active plan to harm yourself. Can you tell me more about that?
Patient: Yes, I was planning on killing myself with the carbon monoxide poisoning by turning on the engines of four cars parked in the garage.
Doctor: I see. According to you, you felt better at the time of the last admission and these suicidal thoughts just returned two to three days back. Can you tell me more about that?
Patient: Yes, I thought I was doing better, but these thoughts just keep coming back.
Doctor: I see. It says in your clinical note that you had multiple admissions and emergency department visits related to your psychiatric conditions as well as five suicidal attempts. Can you tell me more about those?
Patient: Yes, I have been struggling with this for a long time.
Doctor: I see. During one of your admissions, you were evaluated for ECT by a psychiatrist but the decision was made in favor of dialectical behavior therapy (DBT) as they felt these symptoms are because of your BPD. Can you tell me more about that?
Patient: Yes, they thought that DBT would be more helpful for me in coping with my day-to-day issues.
Doctor: I see. According to you, you have been compliant with the therapy that has helped you in coping with your day-to-day issues. Can you tell me more about that?
Patient: Yes, it has helped me a lot, but I still struggle with these active and passive suicidal thoughts.
Doctor: I see. According to you, you have never recovered from these active and passive suicidal thoughts which have progressed to an even worse state in the last four months. Can you tell me more about that?
Patient: Yes, they just keep getting worse and worse. I don't know what to do anymore.
Doctor: I see. On further evaluation, you reported feelings of hopelessness and worthlessness most of the time along with a guilt of things for what you have done in the past. Can you tell me more about that?
Patient: Yes, I just feel so worthless all the time. I can't stop thinking about all the mistakes I have made.
Doctor: I see. You also reported a decrease in sleep to about five hours per night along with difficulty in staying asleep and poor appetite and energy. Can you tell me more about that?
Patient: Yes, I just can't seem to sleep or eat anymore. I feel so tired all the time.
Doctor: I see. It's important that we address these issues and get you the help you need. We will work together to come up with a plan that works for you.

Doctor: Great. The final routine monitoring before delivery was performed at 35 weeks and 5 days of gestation, and the maximum vertical pockets of the twins were observed to be 4.2 and 3.6 cm, respectively, with cardiotocography showing reassuring fetal status patterns for both.

Doctor: However, I understand that you complained of diminished fetal movement at 35 weeks and 6 days of gestation.
Patient: Yes, that's right.
Doctor: And the IUD of one fetus was confirmed by ultrasonography, correct?
Patient: Yes.
Doctor: In this case, an emergency cesarean section was performed, and you delivered a 2306 g surviving twin male infant, and a 1994 g dead twin male infant without any definite anomalies.
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: I'm sorry to hear that. And no autopsy was performed as consent could not be obtained from the parents, correct?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: The surviving infant's hemoglobin was 13.9 g/dL, and ultrasonography of the head revealed no abnormal findings at birth, correct?
Patient: Yes, that's right.

Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: I see. His placenta was peculiar in that both UCIs were observed to be centrally located and in close proximity on the placenta.
Patient: Yes, that's right.
Doctor: And we did not observe any specific placental and umbilical cord findings during the fetal period, correct?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: The placenta was 24 × 19 cm and weighed 778 g, and both umbilical cords were found to be of unusual thickness and of 45 and 48 cm in length, respectively, and both were composed of double arteries and a single vein, correct?

ideal_response: A 34-year-old Japanese woman in her second spontaneous pregnancy was referred to Takeda General Hospital at 17 weeks of gestation and diagnosed with a MCDA twin pregnancy. She was admitted to our hospital at 30 weeks' for management of potential premature delivery. She was regularly monitored by conventional ultrasound to assess growth and amniotic fluid volume, and by Doppler ultrasound of the umbilical artery (Table ). No TTTS complications were observed during hospitalization. The final routine monitoring before delivery was performed at 35 weeks and 5 days of gestation; and the maximum vertical pockets of the MCDA twins were observed to be 4.2 and 3.6 cm, respectively, with cardiotocography showing reassuring fetal status patterns for both. However, she complained of diminished fetal movement at 35 weeks and 6 days of gestation (approximately 12 h later; at the final confirmation of normal cardiac sound for both twins by fetal Doppler ultrasonography), and the IUD of one fetus was confirmed by ultrasonography. Emergency cesarean section was performed, and the patient delivered a 2306 g surviving twin male infant, and a 1994 g dead twin male infant without any definite anomalies. No autopsy was performed as consent could not be obtained from the parents. The surviving infant's hemoglobin was 13.9 g/dL, and ultrasonography of the head revealed no abnormal findings at birth. Although he showed no cardiac or renal dysfunction after birth, he was diagnosed with large cystic periventricular leukomalacia (PVL) on the basis of magnetic resonance imaging findings at 13 days after birth (Fig. ). His placenta was peculiar in that both UCIs were observed to be centrally located and in close proximity on the placenta (Fig. A). We did not observe any specific placental and umbilical cord findings during the fetal period. The placenta was 24 × 19 cm and weighed 778 g. The umbilical cords were found to be of unusual thickness and of 45 and 48 cm in length, respectively. Both umbilical cords were composed of double arteries and a single vein,
